characters: AT THE EDGE OF THE FIELD -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow triangles inside red squares. Water spreading over tiles. Grimy foam. The tile floor of a long and narrow patio stretching thro the entire house: On one end, a black metal door gives on the street. The door has frosted glass windows, two of wh are broken, courtesy of some dejected goalee. CLEO, Cleotilde/Cleodegaria Gutiérrez, a Mixtec indigenou woman, about 26 years old, walks across the patio, nudgin water over the wet floor with a squeegee. As she reaches the other end, the foam has amassed in a corner, timidly showing off its shiny little white bubble but - A GUSH OF WATER surprises and drags the stubborn little bubbles to the corner where they finally vanish, whirling into the sewer. Cleo picks up the brooms and buckets and carries them to

dialogues.speaker: THE SMALL PATIO -
dialogues.text: Which is enclosed between the kitchen, the garage and the house. She opens the door to a small closet, puts away th brooms and buckets, walks into a small bathroom and close the door. The patio remains silent except for a radio announcer, hi enthusiasm melting in the distance, and the sad song of t caged little birds. The toilet flushes. Then: water from the sink. A beat, th door opens. Cleo dries her hands on her apron, enters the kitchen and disappears behind the door connecting it to the house.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Cleo crosses the dark, antique wood breakfast room, then modern light and angled wood dining room and goes up the stairs, reaching the hall. Beyond the hall there are two living rooms, one with heav green velvet sofas and antique cabinets with records and stereo. There’s a piano next to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other living room, with its light sofas and cocktail and siphon attempts to look more modern. There’s a giant painting in red and purple hues of a woma leaning on a clay pitcher. In the other living room, there’s another painting, also large but more somber: In a dark stone cell, a monk bring solace to a shackled prisoner who covers his face with hi hands in desperation.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The stairs go up to a central hall surrounded by four bedrooms and an enormous bathroom. Cleo makes up the bedroom: the double bed is already made has an ornate mahogany headboard that matches the night tables. She collects the dirty clothes from the floor and carries them out to the hall where she piles them up onto a growi mound of laundry. The upstairs hallway doubles as a TV room. The bathroom i yet to be cleaned but two out of three bedrooms are completely done. Cleo walks into a room with two small beds for the kids. picks up the clothes first, and then puts away the boy an girl toys spread across the entire floor. She's started making one of the beds when she hears someo calling from downstairs -

dialogues.speaker: ADELA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Manita! It’s almost one...! Startled, Cleo exclaims -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Ay, chict...! She exits the bedroom carrying dirty laundry. In the hallway, she gathers the pile of clothing and carr it, hurrying down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Cleo heads down the stairs, carrying the pile of clothes.  3. She crosses the hall and dining rooms and disappears behi the door that opens to the kitchen. After a beat, through -

dialogues.speaker: THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: We see her exit to the small patio. She leaves the clothes at the foot of the metal stairs th lead to the roof and hurries out to the street.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Tepeji street spans barely two blocks, halved by Monterre Avenue, its tired homes built in the 1930s. Sad and defeated, Tepeji 21 sits in the middle of the blo resting on its solid ground, which blends with the grey concrete of the sidewalk. The house is all white save for an almost-maroon red stri running along its facade and for the black wrought iron o the windows and doors. Next to the upper left hand corner of the door there’s a ceramic tile number: 21. The door opens and Cleo exits. She hurries out to the Avenue and once she reaches the corner, she turns right.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Cleo leaves Tepeji and walks down the avenue where there’ considerable amount of traffic. As she reaches the corner, she crosses the avenue and continues on -

dialogues.speaker: TLAXCALA STREET -
dialogues.text: She passes a pharmacy, a convenience store, a bakery and beauty salon.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A small crowd gathers by the kindergarten entrance. It’s pickup time. Cleo arrives and goes into the school. After moment, she comes out with PEPE, a 5 year-old boy carryin barely dried “work of art”. EXT —- TLAXCALA STREET - DAY  4. Cleo walks next to Pepe, who carries his “work of art”: j a little kid in shorts and t-shirt. Pepe walks, skipping around not to step on the line. Cleo carries his lunch box. Suddenly, Pepe stops and sits down. Cleo keeps walking a steps, then stops, turns around -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: I'm tired.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Well, let’s go then so we can get home. As soon as we get there you can go straight to bed!

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: I can’t. Cleo pretends to keep walking.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mom! Cleo stops and turns around -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Of course you can! Come on! Let’s go!

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: I said I can’t!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: If I went to bed every time I thought “I can’t”, I would live in bed!

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: I’m not in bed. Cleo takes his hand -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Come on, there’s pasta soup... Pepe gets up —

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Oocooooocoh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he starts with heavy and lazy steps.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mooooocco000o00o0m!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: C'mon little soldier, 1, 2, 3, 4... march! The two march hand in hand.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Cleo and Pepe walk in: he’s carrying his “work of art” wh she carries the lunch box. They listen to Adela calling h

dialogues.speaker: ADELA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (In Mixtec) Hurry up, manita! Fermin is on the phone! Cleo hurries and goes inside the house to answer.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Adela is cooking: pots simmer on the stove. Cleo walks in leaving the lunch box on the table.

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: (In Mixtec) So, what did he say?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Nothing! He just called to say hi! Cleo picks up dishes and glasses, carries them out. Adela stirs the soup. Cleo comes in again and opens the silverware drawer.

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: Sure... Now you’ve stolen my boyfriend, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You crazy? Fermin is only my friend. Plus, you’re the one who introduced us.

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: Ay, manita! Look at you! I’m just messing with you. I only went out twice with him and didn’t even let him kiss me. We hear the street door opening and with it a commotion o kids.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: They’re here... Cleo exits to -

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Cleo reaches the patio just as - Two children run in - TONO, 12 years old and PACO, 11. The two rush into the ho and we hear them go up the stairs. Soon after, SOFI, an 8 year-old girl comes in. She’s very pretty although her brothers constantly pick on her, call her fat. Trailing behind, comes SENORA TERESA, a 65 year-old widow hair completely white, walking with a limp. IGNACIO, the 45 year-old driver, follows her, carrying a grocery bag.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Cleo cuts Pepe’s meat with a knife, she cuts ever-smaller pieces, until only tiny squares of steak remain. She dous them with lemon. SOFI impatiently waits her turn. PACO eats his meat while he talks -

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: A friend told me that a kid in his cousin’s school was killed by a soldier because he threw a water balloon at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tofio listens skeptically -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOF
dialogues.text: backpack a: Sefliora Sof of art” - She sits -

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: Says who?

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Says Flores. If you don’t believe me, ask him. He says he was in Chapultepec, near the new one, and that he was with his brother, throwing water balloons down at the passing cars and so an army Jeep passed and they threw one and the soldier got off and shot him.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Jesus! And what happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: What do you mean, what happened? He got shot in the head, he’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Horrible! TA enters through the hallway door, carrying a nd a bunch of papers from the dining room table -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Hello children, what are you eating?

dialogues.speaker: SOFI AND PEPE
dialogues.text: Mom! ia kisses each one hello. Pepe shows her his “work

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Look, mommy...

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Beautiful! Did you make that all by yourself?

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Yes, and look: there’s pasta soup!

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Yummm, delicious!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleo, please don’t let the kids touch those papers-they’re exams I have to grade.

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: Is there any watermelon?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: No, love. Strawberries and cream.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: I want some! Cleo gets up, taking some dirty dishes with her-

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: What about you, Tofno?

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: I guess so. Cleo goes to -

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Cleo comes in with the dirty dishes, puts them in the sin Ignacio and Adela eat at a small table. Cleo takes a clean bowl and starts pouring soup -—

dialogues.speaker: . CLEO
dialogues.text: Andali, the sefora is here. Sofia and Tofio want their strawberries... Adela gets up, slowly, and puts some plates, spoons, strawberries, sugar and cream on a platter. She looks at with a question and smiles. Cleo blushes and leaves, carrying her platter.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Sefiora Sofia eats her soup. Cleo fixes the strawberries and cream on plates.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Cleo, could you please send the senor's two suits to the dry cleaners. It has to be today because he’s leaving on Friday and has to pack them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, ma’am, I'll take them.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Is dad going on a trip?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: He’s going to Quebec for a conference.

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Where’s that?

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: How come you don’t know, silly?

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: I don’t. So what?

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: It’s in Canada.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Is he flying Eastern?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I think it’s Panam. Cleo serves Sofi a plate of strawberries and cream. SENORA SOF{A (CONT’D) No sugar for Sofi, or she’ll get fat.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Cleo washes clothes, occasionally humming to a song comin out of a yellow radio. The metallic creak of the stairs announces the arrival of Paco, followed by Pepe.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: You know you can’t come up here.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: I looked after him the whole way up.  10.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Your mom is going to be angry. But Paco has started his game, pulling Pepe along with hi

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: I’m going to come out of here and you come over here, and when I get to here you’1l shoot me, but I’11 shoot you first and you’ll fall dead... Like this... with your arms wide open... Paco takes bullets like Sonny Corleone against the wall o the neighboring house.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Just don’t play next to the edge.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: C'mon... Paco moves away on the roof while Pepe hides behind the w tank. Paco comes back, but now hiding like an enemy spy all the to the water tank. He tries to go around it, with his gun held high, but - Pepe comes at him from behind, with murderous intent. Paco reacts and turns around, tries to point with his gun Pepe sprays him with sure shots and hides behind the wate tank leaving Paco confused at first, then furious-—

dialogues.speaker: PACO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were supposed to die! From behind the water tank, Pepe defies him -

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Why aren’t you the one who dies?

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Cause it’s my game.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Then I don’t wanna play anymore.  11.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Well, then I don’t want you to play, sissy. He walks off, angry. He goes down the staircase, each ste resonating with metallic moans. Pepe walks over to see him go and stops in the middle of roof, clearly disappointed. He stays there for a long time, until suddenly - A spray of invisible bullets shoots through him and Pepe falls dead, his arms spread open, like Paco said. And he stays there, lying down motionless on the ground. Cleo dries her hands and walks over to him. She stops and watches him -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: What happened to you? Without opening his eyes, Pepe answers from the ground.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: I’m dead.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Well, let’s go down then.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: I can’t. I’m dead.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Then come back to life, we have to go down!

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: If you die, you can’t live again.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Now what am I going to do without my Pepe!? Cleo sits on the ground next to Pepe, who remains motionl

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t live without my Pepe! Cleo lies down next to Pepe, arms also extended, and clos her eyes -  12.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m also dead. And so she remains still, Pepe next to her. A DC 8 flies overhead. Pepe opens an eye to see Cleo. She’s not moving and seems to be breathing at all. Pepe reaches his hand and takes Cleo’s.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Cleo...? But Cleo’s not moving. Pepe sits up -—

dialogues.speaker: PEPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cleo...?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I’m dead.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: No! C’mon, get up!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Didn't you say that was impossible?

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Cleo, stop it! But Cleo doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cleo! She remains still.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cleeoo! Pepe’s starting to get scared -

dialogues.speaker: PEPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cleeeeeeeeooooooo! Cleo opens her eyes and smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I’m playing your game. Let’s see... shall we play a little longer? Pepe lies down next to her, arms outstretched.  13.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Close your eyes. They both close their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I like being dead. Pepe holds her hand. The two of them lie dead on the roof - The afternoon quiet hours have begun. Church bells ring i the distance. All around them, a landscape of roofs mushrooming in all directions. In many of them, other women wash or hang laundry. The wi carries the hum of different radios and dogs barking. The whistle of a sweet potato cart. The quiet universe.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Cleo bathes Sofi and Pepe in the bathtub. Sofi’s hair is full of soap and she plays at making diffe hairdos in the mirror. Pepe has a submarine but isn’t playing with it. He’s pens

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Cleo, if you died right now, would you go to heaven or hell?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: And why would I die?

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: I’m just saying... Heaven or hell?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: You're killing me all the time... Pepe is getting annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it’s a game! Tell me already... heaven or hell? Cleo fills a small bucket with water and tells

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Let’s see, close your eyes... As she pours water to rinse her hair.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd fly straight up to heaven with my little wings.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Paco told me that in his religion class the had a sli-ding show...

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Sli-ding...? Sofi laughs -

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Slide show.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: That thing. About hell. Cleo pours another bucketful on Sofi.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: (uninterested) Hell?

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Yep, paintings and photos....

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Photos?

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Yeah. He said there was fire on all sides... and that while they burn you, there’s some real ugly devils poking you, like this, with irons... and others that bite you or eat your arms....

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Ay chica! horrible! Stop talking about that...! 14. Sofi -  15.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Yeah but it doesn’t matter...!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: What do you mean it doesn’t matter? What about all the fire? Pepe laughs -

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: He says it doesn’t matter cause that’s where he wants to go!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: What? But didn’t you say they burn people there?

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Yes, but Paco says everyone there is naked! His laugh is now roaring -—

dialogues.speaker: PEPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And that you can see all the girls... naked! Pepe is laughing hard, Sofi spits out water and laughs wi him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The frosted glass panels light up and we hear - A horn honking - Ta-ta ta-ta ta-ta ta-taaaaaaa! Behind the door, the powerful and tantalizing hum of a V8 From inside the car, booms XELA radio station playing “Un bal” from Symphonie Fantastique. BORRAS immediately starts barking at the door. Cleo and Adela rush to the patio-

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: Well, he’s in early. Cleo grabs Borras and drags him to the back of the patio.  16.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Don’t you know he’s leaving tomorrow? Adela begins to open the door. Pepe and Sofi peek out from the hall. Holding Borras, Cle orders them to -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait there! The V8 impatiently purrs behind the door and finally - Adela opens the door to reveal - The front of a 1970 2-DOOR BLACK GALAXIE 500. Its powerfu headlights flood the patio all the way to the back, light Cleo who holds Borras. The Galaxie 500 slowly pulls in but it’s too large for th space, leaving only about an inch on each side of the doo The front of the car is in, then it breaks - The left side is about to touch the door frame. The tires turn right accompanied by the SCREECH of rubber against tile. The Galaxie 500 moves further in but then breaks again - The right side is about to touch. The black power steering wheel turns and - The wheels veer left, SCREECHING. It echoes through the patio, syncopated with the waltz emanating from the radio. Sefiora Sofia comes to the hall door next to Sofi and Pep

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Dad’s home early! The car moves forward a couple of inches and stops. The gear shifts to R - The Galaxie 500 backs up a few inches, breaks.  17.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The gear shifts to D - The car inches forward slowly, free of the door frame. It almost halfway in when it stops. The wheels veer right and - SCREECH. And the waltz picks up its rhythm. The car moves forward half a yard and breaks. The tires line straight up and - The Galaxie 500 has made it through the door frame and is entirely inside the patio - As the waltz reaches its grand finale... The car parks right next to the hall entrance door - The engine shuts off, and with it, the music - Sofi and Pepe lunge through the door -

dialogues.speaker: SENOR ANTONIO
dialogues.text: There, there, there.... Let me get out. Sefiora Sofia pulls the children to her and - SENOR ANTONIO comes out of the car, he’s 40 years old wit few white hairs in his beard. He’s still wearing his whit doctor’s coat. The children jump on him immediately -—

dialogues.speaker: SENOR ANTONIO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who? Who? Who are these kids? Sefiora Sofia touches his shoulder. The family comes in. Adela closes the street door and Cleo sets Borras free. H immediately sniffs at the Galaxie 500’s tires.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Gordolfo Gelatino exists his bedroom wearing a robe, stretching his arms lazily -  18. (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: GORDOLFO GELATINO, (ON T.V.)
dialogues.text: Ya se despert6 tu rorro, mMamacita... (your baby’s up, lil’ mama ) Dofia Naborita welcomes him enthusiastically -

dialogues.speaker: DONA NABORITA, (ON T.V.)
dialogues.text: My angel of the mornin’! Si a penas son las dos de la tarde! Ya descansanste de descansar? (It’s barely 2 pm! Have you rested from resting?) The entire family is seated in front of a 1970 ADMIRAL TELEVISION SET. Sofi is perched on Sefior Antonio and Pepe’s on Sefiora S lap, Paco leans on her, cuddling. Tofio, always more dist sits in an armchair. Cleo serves Sefior Antonio strawberries and cream. She pi up a plate with the remains of a concha and beans and hea towards the stairs when - Laughter explodes, courtesy of Los Polivoces. The kids ar laughing hard in their seats. Cleo stops and turns -

dialogues.speaker: ON TV -
dialogues.text: Gordolfo is sitting on the couch, admiring himself in the mirror, while Dofia Naborita irons a pile of clothes. DONA NABORITA (ON T.V.) (CONT’D) Ora si, mi cerecita de jaibol, el edificio me diéd toda su ropa a lavar y voy a poder comprarte ese reloj que tanto te gusta...! (That's right my little highball cherry, the entire building gave me their laundry to wash so I’m going to buy you that watch you like so much...!)

dialogues.speaker: GORDOLFO GELATINO, (ON T.V.)
dialogues.text: No me gusta verte trabajar tanto, mi cabecita blanca adorada! Asi que por favor vete al otro cuarto. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GORDOLFO GELATINO, (ON T.V.)
dialogues.text: (I don’t like to see you working so hard my beloved little white head... so please go to the other room. ) Cleo sets aside the plates and sits down on the floor nex the sofa to watch T.V. Paco holds out his arm to hug her. Pepe tries doing the same but he can’t reach. Cleo extend her arm and hooks it with his.

dialogues.speaker: ON T.V. -
dialogues.text: A bump announces the Wash and Wear, who, minutes later en his boss El Mostachén’s office. He will exploit him, immu to the insults and truths that the Wash and Wear dishes o

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Cleo? Cleo immediately stands up -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Would you bring the doctor some chamomile tea?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. She picks up the plates from the floor and heads downstai

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Adela is washing the dishes. Cleo comes in and leaves the dirty dishes next to the dishwasher.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Move over! She bumps Adela with her hip.

dialogues.speaker: . ADELA
dialogues.text: Orale!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Make some chamomile tea for the senora and get going.  20.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Adela obeys with mock-resignation and dries her hands wit rag -

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: Just don’t take too long... She grabs a pot and pours water from a carboy on the floo

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Cleo walks in with a steaming cup of tea, places it ona table next to Sefiora Sofia. Pepe sleeps in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Can you take him? Cleo takes Pepe and carries him into his room. Sofi follo her. Cleo pauses before going in to watch -

dialogues.speaker: ON T.V. -
dialogues.text: Chano and Chon reveal their faces under their hats. Chano starts asking Chon about penguin sizes. Chon answers and Chano starts howling at the answer. SENORA SOF{A (CONT’D) Off to bed, children... Tofio and Paco grudgingly get up and kiss their parents g night. INT - SOFI AND PEPE’S ROOM - TEPEJI 21 - NIGHT Sofi is lying down on her bed. Cleo sits next to her, tak her hand -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Angelito de la Guarda, mi dulce compania, no me desampares ni de noche ni de dia. No me dejes sola que me perderia... (My guardian angel, sweet company, don’t leave me alone day or night. Don’t leave alone because I’d be lost...) She strokes her face -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Night-night, beautiful Sofi... And she gives her a kiss.  21.

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Good night, Cleo. She closes her eyes. Cleo gets up and turns off the light She exits to -

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: It’s empty. Paco and Tofio’s door is closed but Sefior An and Sefiora Sofia’s is still open. Sefior Antonio sits on bed, taking off his shoes. Sefiora Teresa’s snores echo through the walls. Cleo picks up the teacup, intact and still full, and goes down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Cleo goes down the stairs carrying the tea cup and when s reaches the hall, she goes into the living room to turn o all the lights. She leaves one on, next to the window. She keeps going till she reaches the kitchen door. She wa in.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Cleo enters the kitchen, pours out the tea and rinses the cup. She turns off the light and goes out to the small pa climbing the metal staircase to her room. INT - MAID’S QUARTERS -TEPEJI 21 - NIGHT Cleo walks into the room. Adela is already in her nightgo

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: You took forever! Cleo takes off her dress, rushing.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Turn the light off already! Sefiora Teresa gets angry if she sees the light on! Adela shuts the light and the room is dark although the window is big and lets the moonlight in. Cleo lights a ca and puts it on the floor.  22.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The two of them lie down, lined up in such a way that one feet touch the other one’s feet and -

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Go... The two of them push the upper parts of their bodies toge and try to touch their toes -

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: (groaning) One... And they work on their abs, one after the other - ADELA (CONT’D) (groaning) Two... Between grunts and groans. Sunday, September 20th, 1970

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The festive bustle of a Sunday in downtown Mexico City: families and street vendors everywhere. Cleo and Adela walk in step, hurrying down the sidewalk i moving obstacle race. Adela is faster but Cleo is more agile and tougher. Adela takes the lead but runs into a bus stop with famili getting off. Cleo manages to slip through the crowd and k going. The sidewalk is a little less full, So Adela takes advant of this and catches up just as they arrive to -

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: They stop, exhausted, catching their breath. One leans on car, the other one on a lamp post. Between deep breaths, Cleo lifts a hand, index pointing a the sky -  23.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: (breathless) «-.I won...

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: (breathless) ...No...we’re...tied... Cleo simply shakes her head no.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Hand-painted illustrations on the wall advertise the different kinds of tortas available. On the other wall, a mirror cut into diamond shapes reflects the already abund clientele. Cleo and Adela sit at the bar, enjoying their tortas cuba spilling over with each bite. ADELA (CONT’D) And then Moisés... remember Moisés, from the village? Cleo nods, giving her torta a giant bite, overflowing wit avocado. ADELA (CONT’D) So he was there, boom, boom, boom, and...

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: (laughing) Boom, boom...boom?

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: No silly! Boom, boom, sending me letter after letter... Every time she speaks, Cleo puts her hand over her mouth

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: (curious ) What all was he writing about?

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: Well, that he couldn’t stop thinking about me... about how much he missed me... wanted to see me...

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Aaaaaaayyyyyyy---!  24. (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: That he felt so alone without me...

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Poor guy!

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: That he couldn’t take not seeing me no more...

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Aaaaaaay...

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: And so my cousin, he comes over from the village to run some errands and brings me another letter from Moisés...

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: And so he pulls out the letter and gives it to me... But the letter was there with a bunch of other letters, and as he’s pulling it out, they all spill onto the floor. And so I see one with Moisés’s handwriting, and so I just take it and I open it...! Following the story, Cleo has stopped chewing - ADELA (CONT’D) And sure enough, it was Moisés’s. I can’t stop thinking about you... I want to see you.... I feel so alone without you... I miss you so...

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Pobrecito! Such a nice guy!

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: Sure. Except the letter was for another girl!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Noooooo! She's floored, mouth wide open, a half-chewed piece of to still in her mouth.  25.

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: That bastard sends the same letter to all the girls! The both explode in laughter, covering their mouths with their hands. Other diners turn around and they both hide their faces, trying to repress their laughter. AT THE ENTRANCE -— Two men walk into the torta stand and look around. They s Cleo and Adela sitting at the bar and walk towards them. RAMON, 27, affable, a little overweight and with sideburn wearing a purple shirt with four buttons open down the fr FERMIN, 26, is shy and a little sullen, with the sculpted body of an athlete over which he sports a t-shirt and a leather jacket.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Why so alone eating your tortitassssss...? He startles the two women. Adela gets up immediately and

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: Ramén! The two hug and kiss luxuriantly. Fermin walks over with a shy smile. Cleo gets up and they awkwardly kiss hello.

dialogues.speaker: ADELA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want a torta? Timidly, Fermin points to his stomach -

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: Thanks, I already...

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: If you’re done eating, let’s go, I love watching the previews! EXT —- METROPOLITAN CINEMA - AFTERNOON  26. The entrance to the movie theater is a bazar of STREET VENDORS hawking their wares, reciting lists over and over like a litany, like mantras in a chant. And old woman seated on the floor offers her candies spre out on a piece of fabric in front of her -

dialogues.speaker: CANDY VENDOR
dialogues.text: ...Cigarrettes-gum-chocolates- mazipan-muéganos-—peanuts-gum drops... Behind his makeshift table, another vendor offers “japane peanuts -

dialogues.speaker: PEANUT VENDOR
dialogues.text: Japaneeeeeeeeeeeeeeese peanuts! Japaneeeeeeeeeeeeeeese peanuts! Japaneeeeeeeeeeeeeeese peanuts! A short, chubby lady walks around, a box of Adams gum in

dialogues.speaker: GUM VENDOR
dialogues.text: One peso for Adams chewing gum! Mint flavor, spearmint, cinnamon, tuttifrutti...! A meringue vendor, in his short shirt -

dialogues.speaker: MERINGUE VENDOR
dialogues.text: ...Merengues-merengues-have a delicious merengue!... Magazine vendors, yo-yo and cheap toy vendors... a cacoph of cries accompanied by a barrell organ on the sidewalk. Cleo, Adela, Ramén and Fermin line up at the ticket booth

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: What movie are we watching?

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Who knows. Fermin asks Cleo -

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: You sure you wanna go to the movies...?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Sure. I like movies, don’t you?  27.

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: Well, I mean... it’s so nice out this afternoon, isn’t it? Cleo realizes the sun is shining and turns her had to the

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Yep, sure is clear. She looks at him -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want to go to the Alameda? Fermin smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: Wait a sec... He walks up to Ramon, who is at the top of the line, pull money out of his wallet. Adela takes the opportunity to go see Cleo.

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: So, manita, no movies for you?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Well... it’s so nice out, no?

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Uuuuuuuuuuuuyyyyyy! Right... well, you'll tell me all about it later, Manita. I prefer the darkness. And she walks off with Ramdén who is waiting to go inside theater. Fermin walks back to Cleo and they leave. The street vendors continue their chorus. The organ playe quiet.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The rules hang in a small frame over the door. Disregarde Behind the window, the Sunday afternoon wanes and a fluorescent sign peeks in, advertising the hotel.  28. Behind the open bathroom door, a single bulb lights the s and a rusty mirror. Fermin exits the bathroom carrying a of nunchaku. He’s completely naked. Cleo waits in bed timidly, her slip still on. She blushes she sees Fermin. In front of the bathroom, Fermin present his nunchaku -

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: Jodan Tsuki!... He begins his nunchaku routine. It’s an elaborate and stu choreography, the chained up sticks spinning like helixes around him. The effect is both poetic and a little ridiculous, but Cl hides her smile behind the sheets. Fermin finalizes his routine by striking different positi FERMIN (CONT’D) Jodan Tsuki! Chudan Tsuki! Mae Geri! And he bows. Cleo represses a laugh. FERMIN (CONT’D) What? Cleo covers her smile, asking -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: So, do you train every day?

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: I have to. I owe my life to martial arts. I grew up with nothing, you know? Outside, the crowd’s hustle and bustle seems distant. Fer leaves the nunchaku on a shelf and walks towards the foot the bed - FERMIN (CONT’D) When I was a kid and my ma died... He crosses himself - FERMIN (CONT’D) My aunt took me in... Over there in Neza. And between my cousins who beat me up and the bad influences, I started drinking...and then huffing...I was dying...  29.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He pauses -

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But then I found out about martial arts. And so then those things... well, you know, suddenly everything seemed, well... focused? Fermin pauses for a beat, looks at Cleo -

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t really like telling people about my stuff, but with you it’s... different. He pulls his face close to hers and their lips meet and k softly. But soon Cleo moves her head, bumping Fermin on t nose.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Oh! Sorry...! Fermin pulls her in again and kisses her intensely and wi his mouth locked on Cleo’s he lies down slowly on top of They make love. Wednesday, November 11th, 1970. INT- MAID’S QUARTERS - TEPEJI 21 - DAWN The alarm bell rings. Cleo wakes up and turns it off. She sits up on her bed. The early morning light comes in the window and the house quiet. Adela sleeps placidly in her bed. Cleo gets up in a rush, takes her clothes from the chair, puts on her shoes and hurries out the door.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Cleo rushes down the stairs and into the small bathroom. INT - MAID’S BATHROOM - TEPEJI 21 - DAWN  30. Cleo vomits. The bathroom is clean but has had zero upkeep for a long time. The tiny shower is curtainless and the toilet has n seat and no lid on the water tank. In the sink, two toothbrushes and a squeezed tube of Colg On a small shelf, a jar of Nivea and an unlit votive cand INT - MAID’S BATHROOM - TEPEJI 21 - MOMENTS LATER Cleo takes a shower, the tiny bathroom immediately cloudi with steam.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Cleo comes out of the kitchen and walks across the house, still in gloom although behind the patio windows the firs light of day is already warming. Cleo reaches the stairs and walks up.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Through the younger children’s bedroom door, we can see C whispering to Sofi -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: My little girl... my beautiful little one... She tickles her midriff -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rise and shine... wake up, wake up... it’s a new dawn, it’s a new day... The tickling inches up Sofi’s torso like an army of ants. Sofi smiles but pretends to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Up, up, up little by little... Sofi finally breaks into laughter and drowsily moves her arms.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good morning, my little princess... Sofi hugs her neck.  31.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Andali! Get up... Sofi gets up -

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Bathroom...

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Get going already! Sofi leaves the room and crosses the hall sleepily while places a clean school uniform on the bed. Sefiora Teresa walks out of her bedroom and sees Sofi abo enter the bathroom -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA
dialogues.text: Good morning, Sofi. Sofi goes in without turning back -

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Good morning, grandma... She closes the door. Sefiora Teresa walks down the stairs Cleo goes to Pepe’s bed and gives him a quick kiss, makin sure not to wake him, then leaves the room. She turns the light on in the hall and goes to Tofio and Paco’s room. They’re deep asleep. She crouches down next to Tofio, caressing his head and whispering -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Tofio, Tofio my love, it’s time to wake up... Without even turning around, Tofio slaps her hand off -

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: I’m up... Cleo puts her hands up in the air -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Oh, so he’s already awake! Oh, so no one should touch him!... Tofo gets up, grouchy, and leaves the room.  32.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sofi’s in the bathroom... In the hall, he knocks on the bathroom door -

dialogues.speaker: SOFI, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Busy! Tono knocks louder.

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: Hurry up! I gotta go!

dialogues.speaker: SOFI, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Coming! Cleo sits at the foot of Paco’s bed and pulls one of his out of the covers and puts his socks on without waking hi She sits him up, leans him against her, and takes off the of his pajamas. In the hall, Tofio keeps knocking on the bathroom door -

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: Get out! The bathroom door opens, and Sofi comes out -

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: You can go in now! Tofio walks in straight away and as he closes the door -

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: Fatty...! Sofi walks back into her bedroom. Cleo has managed to put Paco’s t-shirt on. He’s now sitti on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Come on, finish getting dressed. Paco takes off his pajama pants and Cleo walks out to the hall and in to help Sofi.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Sefiora Teresa and Sofi have breakfast at the table. Cleo putting away waxed paper packages into the backpacks on t floor next to each chair.  33. Through the windows, Ignacio is taking the cars out to th street. A portable radio on the table plays XEQK HASTE’S OBSERVAT HOUR -—

dialogues.speaker: HASTE HOUR
dialogues.text: Chocolates Turin! Ricos de principio a fin! Maestro Mecanico Marcos Carrasco garantiza vigoroso control de calidad en la rectificacién de motores... (Turin Chocolates! Delicious from beginning to end! Mechanic Marcos Carrasco guarantees quality control when rectifying motors...) Paco comes out of the kitchen with a Gansito and puts it his backpack, except Sofi sees him -

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: I want a Gansito too!

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: They're mine.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA
dialogues.text: I bought them for everyone.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: But I put them in the freezer.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA
dialogues.text: Come on, give one to Sofi and I’11l buy you a big box just for you. Paco weighs the offer and goes back into the kitchen. Sefiora Teresa has finished her pan dulce dunked in coffe with milk and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hurry up kids, it’s seven twenty already. Paco’s voice pipes in from the kitchen -

dialogues.speaker: PACO, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: It’s seven seventeen! The Haste Hour recites -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: XEQK proporciona la hora del observatorio, misma de Haste. Haste, la Hora de México. Siete de la manana diecisiete minutos. Siete diecisiete... (a beat)... BIIIP (XEQK gives you the time at the observatory, same as Haste’s. Haste, Mexico’s time. Seven in the morning and seventeen minutes. Seven seventeen...) Paco triumphantly exits the kitchen. Sefiora Teresa pulls her tongue at him and walks off to the door. Paco throws her Gansito.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: For you to get fatter... Tofio walks in.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Your juice, Tofio. Tofo sits down -

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: Turn that thing off.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: No, why? Sefiora Teresa is already calling them from the door -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA
dialogues.text: Let’s go! 34. out Sofi Sofi gets up and walks towards Sefiora Teresa who is head out towards the patio -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cleo, hold the dog so I can open the door. Cleo immediately gets up and runs out to the patio. Tofio also gets up and turns the radio volume all the way before leaving. Paco turns it off with a slap -

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: Haha! Sissy!  35.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Before reaching the patio, Paco cries out -

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Shotgun! Tofio downs his juice and follows them.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The Valiant is parked in front of the house, engine idlin Haste Hour on the radio. Cleo waits on the sidewalk, holding Borras from the colla while Sefiora Teresa and the kids scramble messily into t car.

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: Move it!

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: I’m moving! When Sefiora Teresa has managed to get in the car, Ignaci closes the door behind her, waiting for everyone else to close their doors before getting in.

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: Put La Pantera on! Paco turns the dial and the radio station switches to La Pantera right in the middle of a Beetles vs. Creedence vo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .--Por quién votas campeén? Por los Beatles... Un voto mas para el cuarteto de Liverpool que van atras por 18 votos del Cuarteto del Bajou. Por quién votas? Creedence... (Who do you vote for, champ? For the Beatles... One more vote for the Liverpool quartet, trailing 18 votes behind the Bajou quartet. Who do you vote for? Creedence...) Ignacio steps on the clutch letting Paco, who is sitting to him, put the hand gear next to the steering wheel in first.  36. The Valiant drives off and down the street. Cleo sees it the corner and she walks back into the house pulling the inside. She closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Cleo comes in, closing the patio door. She crosses the ha and walks up the stairs. INT - SOFI AND PEPE’S ROOM - TEPEJI 21 - DAY Cleo hides her face in Pepe’s belly. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: I was already up!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Oh goody! So you’re already dressed!

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: C’mon! Get up, let’s get you dressed! Pepe gets up and Cleo dresses him while he talks -

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: You know what I remembered in my dream?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: No, what did you remember?

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: I remembered when I was older.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: When you were older?

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Yes, you were also there, but you were different. Do you remember? Cleo pulls his shorts up.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: A spoon delicately taps on the dome of an egg, cracking i slowly.  37.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cleo takes off the shell and empties out the soft-boiled onto a cup. She puts in salt and little bits of bread. She gives Pepe the cup. He eats. Cleo gets up and takes t dirty dishes into the -

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Cleo comes in at the same time as Adela, her hair wet, through the small patio door.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Good night!

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you wake me?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Well, God forbid you get tired later. Adela looks at her with a crooked smile. Cleo spreads marmalade on a piece of bread and places it on another. They hear Sefiora Sofia walk into the Breakfast Room -

dialogues.speaker: PEPE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom!

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How’s your egg, my love? Cleo puts the sandwich in a wax paper baggie -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: The Doctor is leaving. Tie Borras up so he can go. Cleo takes the sandwich and a glass of orange juice and h to the breakfast room. Adela goes out to the patio.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Sefiora Sofia is sitting next to Pepe, Cleo comes in with juice.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your juice... (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Pepe can wait to say goodbye to his dad. It doesn’t matter if he’s late.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Yes ma’m. At the back of the hall, Sefior Antonio has come down the stairs, carrying two bags. Cleo rushes to help him.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Leave them there, please, sir...! Sefior Antonio leaves the bags on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: SENOR ANTONIO
dialogues.text: Thanks, Cleo. He walks to the Breakfast Room -

dialogues.speaker: SENOR ANTONIO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good morning, Pepén!

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Daddy! Sefior Antonio gulps down the whole glass of orange juice Cleo heads over to the luggage: she carries the bags and exits -

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Military drums and trumpets echo inside the patio. Cleo carries the bags to the door where Adela is holding Borra the collar. Cleo pauses only to open the door and walks o to -

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A Jr. High marching band marks each step as they file dow the street, sounding drums and trumpets. A 1966 cream colored VW SEDAN waits in front of the house Cleo walks out with the bags and leaves them next to the She opens the door and puts one bag in the rear seat then opens the mechanism in the glove compartment.  39. She gets out of the car and carries the second bag to the front of the car, opens the trunk and puts it in the tiny space. She walks back into the house but sees Sefior Antonio alr walking out through the patio. Sefiora Sofia follows him, carrying Pepe. Sefior Antonio steps on dog shit and stops, disgusted -

dialogues.speaker: SENOR ANTONIO
dialogues.text: Well I’1l be... He rubs the foot on the floor trying to clean it off and keeps walking. On the street, he scrapes the sole of his against the edge of the sidewalk. Sefiora Sofia puts Pepe down on the as they reach the str and walks over to Sefior Antonio, hugging him from the ba Cleo moves back a few steps, Pepe walks over to her and h her hand. Sefiora Sofia starts crying. Sefior Antonio turns around hugs her, uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: We'll be here...

dialogues.speaker: SENOR ANTONIO
dialogues.text: It's just for a few weeks... He disentangles from Sefiora Sofia who heads over to give a snotty kiss which he accepts before sitting at the whee and closing the door. Sefiora Sofia puts her hand on her husband’s shoulder whi turns on his four cylinder engine.

dialogues.speaker: SENOR ANTONIO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bye, Pepe... He shifts into first gear and starts off slowly, forcing Sefiora Sofia to lift her hand, then drives off to the en the street. The VW idles at the corner where it waits for the back of marching band to leave the street taking its martial airs with it, then disappears to the right. Sefiora Sofia is frozen, her hand held up in the air. Cle waits.  40.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Finally, Sefiora Sofia turns, her face upset -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Goddamnit! Clean up that dog shit! She walks up to Pepe and takes his hand -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOF
dialogues.text: I’ll take Pepe. She walks with Pepe to the end of the street, heading in opposite direction as Sefior Antonio. Cleo comes into the house and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Cleo pushes the shit onto a dustpan with a broom. She moves on to the next one, while Borras walks around t patio, oblivious. One by one, she picks them all up.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Cleo opens the trash and throws in the shit. She closes i

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A smeared stain on a red and white tile is all that remai of Borras’s shit. Pale dust falls on the stain until it’s entirely covered. Cleo crosses the patio, dusting soap on each one of the remaining stains. She reaches the street entrance, fills pails of water, pours them on the floor and - One by one, she brushes every single dusted stain in the patio. Sunday November 29, 1970

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The theater is almost full, but emptier towards the back. the last row, Cleo and Fermin sit next to each other, mak out intensely, their hands rubbing each other’s genitals while they kiss.

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: Suck it... Cleo moves back briefly and tries to tell him between sig

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: It’s just that... I haven’t gotten my period this month... But she succumbs, trying to repress a groan of pleasure. kisses and caresses Fermin with greater intensity as he explores her more deeply with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MOVIE
dialogues.text: Finally, Cleo manages to overcome her desire to tell him

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m telling you. I haven’t had my period all month. But Fermin quiets her with a kiss on the mouth. When he g to her neck, Cleo tries to talk between convulsions of pleasure -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think I’m with child. Fermin pauses briefly, then keeps kissing her -

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: Oooohhh, well that’s OK, right?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: That’s OK?

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: Yeah... Cleo smiles and kisses him on the mouth. She lowers her h and gives him a blow job. Fermin holds her head down push her to a rhythm.

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like that... Just. Like. That...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fermin reaches his arms out to grab onto the backs of the neighboring seats and starts moaning.

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes, yeeeeees, yeeeeeeeees, yeeeeeeeeeceeceeces ! He opens his mouth and muffles a cry by biting down on hi hand and when the explosion is over, Cleo comes up, hand her mouth, face splashed with semen. She opens her purse and pulls out a couple of Kleenex. Sh wipes her mouth and face, then her hands, and cuddles on Fermin who is still breathing heavily. The two watch the movie. Cleo is in love.

dialogues.speaker: MOVIE
dialogues.text: Fermin moves softly to get up -

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have to go to the restroom..

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Shhhh... It’s almost over.

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: I gotta go now. Gimme a sec, I'll be right back... He gets up, walking through the empty seats to the aisle then to the exit. Cleo waits till he’s left to look for some gum in her pur She puts it in her mouth. Pulls out another Kleenex, wets with her tongue and wipes her face. The MOVIE reaches the end and the CREDITS roll. Cleo look the exit. PEOPLE start to leave. The LIGHTS COME ON in the theater, SECTION BY SECTION, SLOWLY... Cleo gets up and looks to the exits, leaning onto the sea in front of her. Credits keep rolling with the names of the Stage Crew. The theater is now empty except for Cleo and the screen showing the sound credits.  43.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The velvet curtain closes, interrupting the unfinished credits. Cleo finally heads to the exit.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: New spectators enter the theater, some heading directly t the candy store, where the lines are still short. Cleo wanders through the lobby looking for Fermin but the no sign of him. She walks towards the entrance, heading the opposite direction as the newcomers.

dialogues.speaker: EXT -ENTRANCE -METROPOLITAN CINEMA
dialogues.text: Cleo exits and walks to the middle of the entrance where stops, engrossed between the STREET VENDORS hawking their wares, reciting their different mantras. Her legs seem to fall out from under her and she leans on marquee advertising the upcoming releases. Slowly, she si on the ground between -— An old lady selling her sweets

dialogues.speaker: SWEETS VENDOR
dialogues.text: ...cigarrettes-chewing gum- chocolates-mazipan-muéganos-peanuts-— gum drops-... And a man peddling his magic trick: a small plastic skele that dances on the ground -

dialogues.speaker: SKELETON VENDOR
dialogues.text: No tricks, no ruses, it dances on its own! No strings, no cheating, Don Carlangas dances... Cleo stays still in the midst of a sea of voices -

dialogues.speaker: VENDORS
dialogues.text: ...dapaneeeeeeeeese peanuts! ... Herbie stickers for sale!... Merengues-merengues-get your delicious mereeeeeeengues!... Mint flavored, spearmint, cinnamon, tuttifrutti flavored Adams chiclets!...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Next to Cleo, the small skeleton jumps, shimmies and sudd stops -

dialogues.speaker: SKELETON VENDOR
dialogues.text: What happened, Don Carlangas? You tired? And what are we gonna do about that? The skeleton sits on the floor - SKELETON VENDOR (CONT’D) Aha! Mister Carlangas is resting! Tuesday, December 8th, 1970.

dialogues.speaker: EXT -STREET
dialogues.text: And old Purépecha indigenous man, hunched and with a stra hat carries an enormous and bulky cloth sack, which almos covers his frail figure from the back. He walks down the street at a steady step, stopping only rearrange the heavy sack on his back. He walks past a convenience store, a pharmacy, a bakery, dime store, a stationary store and turns onto -

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Without losing his rhythm, the old man walks in front of old houses built in the 1930s, hunched over, the enormous bulk resting almost vertically on his back. Some houses h renovated, some are in desperate need of a new coat of pa He arrives to Tepeji 21 and stops in front of the door. Slowly he takes the giant load off his back and puts it o the ground. He rings the bell. Inside, we hear Borras running to the door, barking furiously. The old man waits. Borras doesn’t let up, his barks grow ever louder. Cleo approaches -—

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who is it?  45.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN WITH ORANGES
dialogues.text: Oranges! Borras answers, furious.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Coming...! Borras, shut up! The old man picks up the sack while the door opens just enough for Cleo to peek out while grabbing the dog’s coll The old man finishes putting his sack back up on his back

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN WITH ORANGES
dialogues.text: You got the dog?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN WITH ORANGES
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I got him. Come on in. The door opens and Borras immediately lunges for the old but Cleo holds tugs at collar with all her strength. The barks, aggressive, standing on its hind legs. The old man comes into -

dialogues.speaker: EXT -PATIO -TEPEJI 21
dialogues.text: Cleo holds Borras and steps to the side while the old man comes in. The dog’s mouth sprays slob with each bark.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN WITH ORANGES
dialogues.text: Hold him tight. Cleo wrestles with the dog -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Come in, come in... The old man walks cautiously next to Cleo, who is still holding Borras. She closes the door and follows in after keeping her distance. At the far end of the patio, the ol man goes into the -

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The old man stops in front the kitchen and slowly deposit the heavy sack on the floor. Adela comes out of the kitch carrying a wooden crate, which she places on the floor -  46.

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: Good morning, sir...

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN WITH ORANGES
dialogues.text: Morning... How many’ll it be?

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: Thirty. The old man takes his hat off to cool his straight white damp with sweat. His Indigenous face is furrowed by deep wrinkles. He bends over, puts his hands in the sack and p out -
Cleo holds Borras who won’t stop barking.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Pebbles of ice bounce off the ground after falling from t sky. Hail covers the patio.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Drowned out by clouds, the afternoon light fights to pier through the windows. Behind the window: hail over the sma patio. Adela pours coffee in a pot and puts it on a tray that already has a sugar bowl, a little milk pitcher, a spoon a napkin. Next to her, Cleo waits nervously.

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: C’mon manita, you take it. Cleo takes the platter and walks towards the living room. Adela walks with her but stops at the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Cleo exits the kitchen. Adela waits next to the door and watches her cross the hall carrying the coffee tray. Behi the windows, hail pours down. The afternoon light barely mottles the living room curtai and already some lamps are on. In a corner, a Christmas T shows off its many colored lights over a handcrafted nati scene with moss, hay and cardboard landscapes.  47.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: In the modern living room, the children sit at the sofa around Sefiora Sofia. Cleo places the platter on the coffee table next to some sheets of paper and envelopes and pours the coffee. She i about to add some cream, when -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: That’1l be fine, Cleo... Cleo places the cup in front of Sefiora Sofia. She takes cream and pours it while Cleo starts to leave. She stops

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Pardon me, Sefiora Sofi? Sefiora Sofia adds two sugars to her coffee.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: It’s just that... when you have a minute, would you mind if we talk for a little bit?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Yes, just wait a sec. I need to say something to the children. Cleo nods and steps back a few steps, ready to wait.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Feel free to sit down and wait over here. Cleo timidly sits on the sofa. Sefiora Sofia tastes her coffee, the children grow restless.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: I gotta go buy balsa wood to build a model. Sefiora Sofia sips her coffee and good-humoredly says -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: You'll go later. There's something I want to tell you...  48.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Are we going to Disneyland?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: No, we're spending Christmas at my brother Pablo's.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: It’s so boring there!

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Not true! My cousins are there!

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: And for New Year’s we’ll go to the Zavaleta’s hacienda.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Will the Richards be there?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Yes and the Matos and the Larsons.

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: When’s dad coming?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: That's the other thing I wanted to talk to you about. His research is delayed and he’1l have to stay in Quebec a little longer.

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: Will he be back by January? Sefiora Sofia pauses for the briefest instant and when sh takes up the conversation again her tone seems to have changed.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: He doesn’t know. But that’s why I brought you the paper. So you can each write him a letter. She hands out the paper and envelopes to the children -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOF
dialogues.text: Tell him how much you miss him, to come back soon please... Her good humor masks her nervousness.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pepe, you draw him somthing...

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: I know how to write too.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Sure... Toho gets up -

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: Well, first I’m going to go get my balsa wood. Sefior Sofia yells at him -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: You're not going anywhere until you've finished writing your letter! Tofio grabs his papers and rushes off angrily towards the stairs. SENORA SOF{A (CONT’D) Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: To my room. What? Can’t I write the letter in my room either?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Sure, that’s fine. Paco grabs his paper and follows Tofio -

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: I’m going up too. Sefiora Sofia gives the rest of the paper to Sofi.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Sofi, take this to the dining room and help Pepe with his letter. Let me just talk to Cleo for a minute and I’1l come join you. Sofi takes the papers -

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: C'mon Pepe.  50.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Make lots of pretty drawings, Pepe. Sofi, help him write “I miss you a lot, daddy.”

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Sure. Let’s go Pepe. Sofi and Pepe go off with their papers to the dining room table.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: But I’1l write it, OK? Sefiora Sofia watches the kids trail off into the dining She turns to Cleo.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: OK, Cleo. What do you need? Cleo looks at her like a deer in the headlights. She can’ speak.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOF
dialogues.text: Didn't you want to tell me something?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: No, well, yes. It’s just that... But her words fail her. In the back, next to the kitchen door, Adela pretends to clean while she tries to listen -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Yes? Cleo’s eyes fill with tears. Sefiora Sofia worries -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOF
dialogues.text: What’s wrong, Cleo? Cleo just sobs. SENORA SOF{A (CONT’D) Is your mother all right? Cleo nods -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: It’s just that... Sefiora Sofi...  51.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: It’s just that... I think I’m expecting. Sefiora Sofia wasn’t expecting this at all -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: What do you mean, you think?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: It’s just that I haven’t gotten my period.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Since when?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I don’t know... She starts sobbing. Sefiora Sofia sits next to her and hu her.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Oh you silly, silly girl. And who is the dad?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Fermin. Adela’s boyfriend's cousin.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Does he know? Cleo shakes her head -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: He’s disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Silly, silly, silly...!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: You're going to fire me, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: What do you mean fire you? We have to take you to the doctor to get checked. Pepe comes in with his letter -  52.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Look, ma. I drew a plane.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Very good. Now put some hearts on it... (Calling out to Sofi) Sofi! I told you to help your brother write “I miss you.” Sofi answers from the dining room -

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: He won’t let me help him!

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Why is Cleo crying?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: For no reason. She’s got a stomachache. Let’s see, come over here. Let’s write your letter. Sefiora Sofia walks over to the dining room but Pepe walk to Cleo and hugs her. He rubs her belly -

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Sana, sana colita de rana. Si no sanas hoy, sanards manana... (Nursery rhyme to heal boo-boos) Cleo laughs and hugs Pepe, hiding her tears. Thursday, December 10, 1970.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT
dialogues.text: Sefiora Sofia drives silently, hands on the stirring whee but her index fingers moves as if acquiescing at the inte argument going on in her head. Cleo rides next to her. Hair freshly done. She’s changed dress. She is nervous. They come to a cross-street where cars wait for the green light. Sefiora Sofia tries to squeeze into the space betw moving truck and an old jalopy.  53.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Pio, pio, pio, pio... Impossible. The inevitable happens. The Galaxie 500 scrap on both sides, but this doesn’t seem to bother Sefiora So who keeps inching up slowly, despite the crush of twistin metal - SENORA SOF{A (CONT’D) Pio, pio, pio, pio...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The Galaxie 500 moves forward between the truck and the jalopy, scraping its moldings, twisting them, and ripping the side mirror to boot. The Galaxie lurches on amidst the crush of metal sheets u the space is too tight to keep going. The light changes to green and they drive on, except for truck and the jalopy whose irritated drivers exit their vehicles to assess the damage. EXT. — MEDICAL CENTER - CUAUHTEMOC AVE - DAY The modern building site glows proudly with its promise o progress. The Galaxie 500, with its dented sides and dragging a mol enters a parking lot reserved for the doctors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sefiora Sofia and Cleo walk in front of a building displa beautiful murals with Prehispanic motifs and cross the entrance indicating Obstestrics and Gynecology.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Sefiora Sofia and Cleo cross the enormous marble lobby un they reach the elevators resting under a mural of patriot heroes. INT - 8th FLOOR LOBBY -OB/GYN -DAY  54. Sefiora Sofia and Cleo walk out of the elevator to a nurs station at the center of the lobby. Sefiora Sofia approac the head NURSE -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Good day, I have an appointment with Doctor Vélez.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Under what name?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: It’s Doctor Roldan’s wife. The nurse picks up a phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wall to wall picture windows run all along the hallway an the exam rooms. Sefiora Sofia waits with Cleo, who looks out the window o the city stretching out to the west. DOCTOR VELEZ walks in with all the conviction that comes experience. She is 40 years old and wears glasses.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Hello, Margarita. Thank you for seeing us.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ
dialogues.text: Of course, Sofia. With pleasure. They kiss hello.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Remember Cleo? Doctor Vélez turns to Cleo -

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ
dialogues.text: Of course! Hi Cleo, how are you? Cleo suffers from a mix of shyness and fear.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Fine, thank you, doctor.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ
dialogues.text: So, let’s see how you’re doing, Cleo. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She She one

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: holds walks 55. DOCTORA Vé6LEZ (CONT'D) Come with me and tell me all about it... Sofia, you want to come as well?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Margarita. I’1l just go over to say hi to Doctor Zavala.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ
dialogues.text: Well, Cleo and I are going to have a chat. Why don’t we meet in the lobby in forty minutes or so?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Sure. I'll be back then. Cleo’s hand - SENORA SOF{A (CONT’D) Go on Cleo, go with the doctor. back to the lobby. Cleo and Doctor Vélez head to of the exam rooms. — EXAM ROOM - OB/GYN - DAY Cleo is sitting in a gynecological chair. She looks at th instruments on a tray off to the side. They look like medieval torture instruments. The door opens and Doctor Vélez comes in. She sits on a c between Cleo’s legs and starts to put on latex gloves -

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ
dialogues.text: All right then. Cleo, tell me. Cleo hesitates -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: It’s just that.... That...

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ
dialogues.text: It’s OK Cleo, you can talk to me...

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: It’s that I haven’t gotten my period.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ
dialogues.text: Since when?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: About two months maybe?  56.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ
dialogues.text: OK. And you’ve been sexually active for how long? Cleo blushes and cannot bring herself to answer.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you had many partners?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Oh no! Never!

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ
dialogues.text: Do you use protection? Cleo apparently doesn’t understand the question.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you use condoms? Cleo’s tears are the only answer. Doctor takes the specul and smears Vaseline on it.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When was the last time you got checked?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Probably three or four years ago when I came to see you.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ
dialogues.text: That’s not good, Cleo. You have to get checked twice a year.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Yes, doctor.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ
dialogues.text: Well, let’s see how you’re doing. This is going to feel a little cold... Doctor Vélez slides the speculum in between Cleo’s legs. Cleo’s face confirms it’s not only cold, it’s also painfu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleo walks down the hallway with Doctor Vélez. At the far of the lobby, they can see Sefiora Sofia talking with Doc Zavala, 45 years old.  57.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: When she sees Cleo, Sefiora Sofia interrupts her chat wit Doctor Zavala. Cleo is crying and is still disturbed. Doctor Vélez and Doctor Zavala kiss hello -

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ
dialogues.text: Hi, Mario...

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR ZAVALA
dialogues.text: Doctoress...

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: How’s Cleo doing?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ
dialogues.text: Cleo is ten weeks pregnant. She’s very healthy and very strong and so is her baby. One thing: she has to get an iron shot every two weeks. I’ve given her a prescription.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: When’s she due?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ
dialogues.text: Sometime around the end of June.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Oh Margarita, thank you so much for seeing her.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ
dialogues.text: It’s nothing! I missed her, right Cleo? OK, I’m off... She kisses Sefiora Sofia goodbye -

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bye, Cleo. See you next month for your check up.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Yes, doctor. Thank you. Doctora Vélez walks off down the hallway. Sefiora Sofia t to see Cleo -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Cleo, why don’t you go down to the third floor to see the new-born babies while I finish up here with Doctor Zavala?  58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of cribs in a row, each one with its own new-born rolled up in a blanket. Cleo watches them through the window. Some sleep and others cry anxiously. Four cribs project strong lights on babies with masks, an one side - In an INCUBATOR - A premature baby, tiny and fragile is plugged into tubes barely bind him to life. Cleo watches, fascinated. Suddenly - A great block of plaster falls off the ceiling and lands the incubator, covering it completely. Thursday, December 31st, 1970. INT/EXT - ‘64 VALIANT - PUEBLA FREEWAY EXIT - CERRO LA CALDERA -— DAY Sefiora Sofia drives, her index finger in its eternal argument. Cleo rides next to her, and between them, Pepe. Tofio, Paco and Sofi are in the back seat. The radio play Radio Exitos. Pepe looks through the rearview mirror off into the dista

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Why does the mountain spell LEA? (READ)

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: So that you kids read. See? Even the mountain is asking.

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: It’s the initials for Luis Echeverria Alvarez, dummy.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Don’t call him that. He’s 5. He doesn’t have to know who Echeverria is. Explain it to him.

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: He’s the president!

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Isn't it Gustavo Diaz Ordaz?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Not anymore, Sofi. It’s now Luis Echeverria, since December 1st.

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Oooooh...

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Cleo really likes Echeverria. Yuck!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Well, yeah. His wife Dofia Ester is always dressed in huipiles and Oaxacan clothing. He likes us Indians.

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: But my uncle Alberto says he’s the one who ordered the students killed two years ago.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Noooooo!

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: He was the Minister of the Interior.

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Why did he kill the students?

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: ‘Cause they didn’t do their homework.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Enough, Tofio. No, Sofi, Tofio is just messing with you.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Well I don’t like him. Why does he write on the mountain? It’s not his!  60. EXT. —- PUEBLA FREEWAY - CERRO LA CALDERA - DAY The Valiant plows on eastward. In the background the Cerr Caldera, longing to be a mountain, delineates the boundar the city as it melts into the slums. The west slope of the hill has been desecrated by three immense white letters extending almost all along and acro its dry surface - LEA. Like a curse. EXT. - ZAVALETA HACIENDA —- DAY A great adobe wall surrounds an immense property in the middle of fields. The Valiant crosses an enormous gate in EXT. —- ENTRANCE - ZAVALETA HACIENDA - DAY A road crosses the enormous walled esplanade. In the background, the beautiful wall of the hacienda, a monumen Profirian estates. The Valiant reaches the Big House. A dozen cars are parke a row to one side of the road. All large luxury cars of t year: LTDs, Impalas and Country Squires. The ‘64 Valiant parks between an LTD and a Country Squire making its mileage and its peeling paint very obvious. Th get out of the car. Sefiora Sofia opens the trunk and Cleo starts to pull out luggage, her belly barely noticeable. A group of people comes out of the Big House to greet the three adults, some kids and several servants. CLAUDIA DE BARCENA, 38, SAMANTHA LARSSON, also 38, a high-class Mexi with died blond hair and MOLLY EDWARDS, an affable blond Welsh woman, 37, all throw their arms up in the air -

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Comadre!

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT
dialogues.text: BENITA, 55 years old, the Hacienda housekeeper, guides Cl down a long corridor. Both carry several bags some in the hands others hanging from their shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: BENITA
dialogues.text: You sure you can carry that?  61.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m with child, not sick. What? You tired already? Cleo hurries forward. Benita does the same, following her

dialogues.speaker: BENITA
dialogues.text: As if!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I haven't seen you for six months and you got old on me. The two women race hurriedly, buried under bags like ants carrying several times their own weight. Benita catches up with Cleo, who hurries on and overtakes her. But Benita stops -

dialogues.speaker: BENITA
dialogues.text: Where you going? Cleo stops. Benita is standing next to a door -

dialogues.speaker: BENITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've gone too far. What? Since you're pregnant you forget everything? Cleo smiles and walks back.
