INT. - CHILDREN’S ROOM - HACIENDA - DAY A hall full of bunk beds, rudimentary but functional. The are several bags next to the beds and there are toys on t of some already. Lined up along all the walls there are stuffed dog heads. Cleo leaves the luggage next to a bunk bed and looks at t heads.

dialogues.speaker: BENITA
dialogues.text: Sefior José had the room redecorated. They’re the Hacienda dogs. Look... They were all in storage. They look at a German Shepherd’s head with glass eyes.  62.

dialogues.speaker: BENITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, that there is Pirata. He lived here in 1911. A small plaque confirms this. It also indicates his name Pirata. Cleo looks on, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Pirata...

dialogues.speaker: BENITA
dialogues.text: And do you remember Canela?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Yeah, where’s she at?

dialogues.speaker: BENITA
dialogues.text: Look at her. Cleo looks at an Irish Setter’s head.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Yikes!

dialogues.speaker: BENITA
dialogues.text: She died during the summer. Cleo looks at Canela, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: They say she must have eaten a poisoned rat. But I think it was the villagers who are bothering Don José again about the land... Canela looks at them with her glass eyes. EXT —- SMALL CLEARING IN THE WOODS - HACIENDA - DAY The winter light filters through the trees and reflects o the great puddle stretching between the clearing and the woods. Children run between the trees throwing firecrackers, two dogs follow them, jumping in the puddle. Adults are practicing shooting bottles lined up on tree stumps with caliber pistols at the other end of the clearing.  63. With the exception of nannies and servants looking after younger children, everyone is white and, except for Sefio Sofia and her children, they’re dressed in imported cloth The sound of shots fuses with the firecrackers. Tofio plays “tochito” flag-football with PEPE DE LA BARCE 13, EDUARDO LARSSON, a 12 year-old redhead, and RICKY EDWARDS, 11. Cleo looks after Pepe and keeps LUPE, 30, company as well YOLA, 22, who look after JORGE DE LA BARCENA, 7, who suff from intellectual disability, and partial paralysis in a and arm, and his brother MEMO, 5, who has autism spectre disorder. They’re sitting on a tablecloth, playing with Matchbox cars. A little further back, GLORIA, 34, who works as a nanny w the Edwards’, sits on another tablecloth with a toy china set, probably more expensive than a real one, and looks a Sofi who is playing with JULY EDWARDS, 7, VERO MATOS, 8, ANDREA, a girl whose blond hair is almost white, also 8. GERARDO LARSSON, 10, a flamboyant chubby redhead plays wi them too. Paco, along with RODRI DE LA BARCENA, 10, ALEX MATOS, 10 ANDY EDWARDS, 8, appear from behind the trees and throw firecrackers at the girls. They scream. Some even cry.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I saw you, Paco! Get out of here! The boys run off, laughing and splashing across the puddl

dialogues.speaker: LUPE
dialogues.text: Rodri! Don’t run in the water! You're soaking wet! Dr. ALEJANDRO MATOS, 40, with a goatee, shoots while smok his pipe. Next to him, RICARDO EDWARDS, friendly, 39, OVE LARSSON, towering redheaded shy Norwegian, 41, and LESLIE MATOS, a blond American, 38 also shoot while DR. JOSE DE LA BARCEN 41, waits his turn and CELSO, the hacienda foreman, 35, reloads the guns.

dialogues.speaker: DR. JOSE DE LA BARCENA
dialogues.text: Celso, do you still have bullets or should I send Lupe to get the ones in the chest?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A few yards away, Sofia, Claudia, Molly and Samantha sit folding chairs, chatting. Sefiora Sofia sees the boys running through the trees. Sh gets up and yells -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Don’t run over there, you could get shot! Molly seconds her, with her thick accent -

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Boys! Vayase! Andy, get back! FLOR, 17, a servant from the Hacienda, stands at a table a cooler, pouring the adults drinks, LOLA, 12 going on 19, made up, dressed in a tiny mini-ski and platform shoes, takes advantage of the adults’ distraction to pour whisky into her Coca-Cola. Next to he CLAU DE LA BARCENA, 11, seems amused, but her curiosity d not yet supersede her obedience. ON THE CHILDREN'S TABLECLOTH -— The interaction with Jorge and Memo is difficult so Pepe bored and watches the shooting party. He gets up and walk over there.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Wait, Pepe. Where are you going? Pepe just points and keeps walking. Cleo follows him and reach the - SHOOTING PARTY -— Where Dr. Alejandro Matos has fired his eight rounds and to Celso to recharge his gun. He calls to the women on th folding chairs -

dialogues.speaker: DR. ALEJANDRO MATOS
dialogues.text: What? Don’t ladies shoot? The women decline with their hands -

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Leslie is our representative!  65.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ALEJANDRO MATOS
dialogues.text: Leslie doesn’t count, she’s a gringa. The women laugh. Claudia gets up -

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDIA
dialogues.text: Coming!

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: (In English) Yes, Claudia. You show them, girl! Celso gives Alejandro the reloaded gun while Leslie arriv with hers. Celso takes it and quickly reloads it. Pepe pi up the empty cartridges off the ground. Cleo helps him. Celso gives Alejandro a loaded gun, who gives it to Claud

dialogues.speaker: DR. ALEJANDRO MATOS
dialogues.text: (in English) Leslie, could you help Claudia?

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE
dialogues.text: Come. Point the gun to the floor when you’re not using it. Cokes in hand, Clau and Lola mingle with the adults. They come upon Leslie -

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (In English) C’mon, Lola. You really have to wear a miniskirt and platform shoes? We’re in the woods. Lola keeps walking and pays no attention to her mother.

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDIA
dialogues.text: Forget her. You look great, Lola. Lola and Clau reach the shooting party and its male acceptance.

dialogues.speaker: DR. JOSE DE LA BARCENA
dialogues.text: Let’s see Lola, you want to shoot?

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Sure. Lola walks up to José who gives her the gun while he hugs from the back, to “help” her shoot.  66.

dialogues.speaker: DR. JOSE DE LA BARCENA
dialogues.text: Don’t close your eyes when you shoot... Cleo looks at Alejandro walking over to the drink table tended by Flor.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ALEJANDRO MATOS
dialogues.text: Can you pour me a whisky with two ice cubes? Flor fixes his drink.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE SHOOTING PARTY -
dialogues.text: Everyone celebrates Claudia’s nailing two bottles. She sh four more shots in a row and pops off four more bottles. Everyone celebrates -—

dialogues.speaker: RICARDO EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Be careful Pepe, your wife is like a guerrilla fighter! Everyone laughs. Flor hands Alejandro his whisky and, taking advantage of confusion, he spanks her. Flor runs away, terrified. More bottles explode.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Dozens of floor lamps and table lamps light an immense na with an enormous chimney guzzling up thick logs facing a broad living room with huge leather sofas decorated with furs. Adults converse, some sitting on the couches, others standing, all are drinking and some are smoking. Pepe is Sofi’s lap, and Gerardo is next to his mother. Yvonne Elliman’s voice rings through the air, singing “I Don’t Know How to Love You.” The girls play cards in a lo table in front of the French window that opens to a terra Outside, the boys throw firecrackers and rockets. Other boys play “Trominos” on the floor and in a smaller living room, Lola, drink in hand, gossips with Clau. Cleo is with Yola, who looks after Memo, who is obsessive turning a plate on the floor, and after Jorge, who plays a little car.  67.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Pepe, July Edwards and Andrew Larsson come in from the terrace howling and laughing, chased after by a strange monster. It’s a scarecrow with a straw body and long furs wooden mask covering its face. Something like a pagan spirit, rum and coke in hand, now chasing after the younger children, who flee happily. Cleo sees Flor walk in with a tray carrying too many milk and milkshakes. She hurries to help her - The milk glasses dance perilously on the platter while Fl loses her balance, but Cleo rushes just in the nick of ti Together they walk over to the table and serve beverages the girls. The scratch of a needle on a record as the metals of an orchestra blast a mambo rhythm: the tune changes to Perez Prado’s “Coraz6n de Melén.” Samantha jumps up with a cry and starts to dance -

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Come on, comadre! Sofia and Molly get up and dance with her. Ricardo Edward his Ricky Ricardo impersonation, walks by yelling -

dialogues.speaker: RICARDO EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Co-ra-z6n de melén, de meldén meldn! Corazon! He joins in the dancing. Alejandro follows and dances wit Sofia. Lola and Clau also join, Gerardo dances with his mother. Ove with July. Benita comes into the living room and looks around. Molly trying to get Vero and Andrea to go to bed, but they don’ want to. Cleo and Flor look on, amused, sucked in by the Mambo. Cl sees - Pepe, joining the dance and going up to his mother, who p no attention since she’s too busy dancing with Alejandro. Benita walks up to Cleo.

dialogues.speaker: BENITA
dialogues.text: Come her for a sec.  68.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cleo looks at her, confused -

dialogues.speaker: BENITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just come over for a sec. Cleo looks around -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: But... what if?

dialogues.speaker: BENITA
dialogues.text: What? Is a kid going to cry because he lost at marbles or his brother stepped on him? Cleo looks at her, amused, and follows her. They cross th room to the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: RICARDO EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Co-ra-z6n de me-lén, de me-lén, me- 16n, co-ra-zén!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benita guides Cleo, who follows amused and curious down t corridor lit with candles. The leave the MAMBO behind and down -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stone staircase leads down to an internal patio that doubles as storage. A couple of men chat, lit by the light from a kitchen win Inside there’s a racket around an accordion exhaling a ranchera-style polka. Three dogs meander about the patio, waiting for a New Yea gift. Benita and Cleo walk into -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hall with a vaulted ceiling lit by bare light bulbs hos an enormous ancient kitchen with wood burning stoves, a g table, a Mabe stove and two 1961 refrigerators.  69.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Hacienda WORKERS celebrate New Year’s. Benita guides to the table. Women are serving plates of food from large clay pots. A year-old man plays the accordion and some spontaneous guy improvises a quebradita dance with Gloria, who is clearly drunk. She sees Cleo -

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: What? They finally let you out? Cleo laughs. At the table, everyone drinks, some eat, som are dressed for the occasion, many are not. A 1959 televi set transmits Channel 2’s New Year’s special.

dialogues.speaker: BENITA
dialogues.text: What’1l you have?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Nothing, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BENITA
dialogues.text: What? You’re not going to toast the New Year with us? What, you only speak English now?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: It’s just that... the baby...

dialogues.speaker: BENITA
dialogues.text: A drink on New Year’s will do it good. Celebrate while you can. See that guy with the hat? Cleo sees a man with a hat talking somberly with two othe men -

dialogues.speaker: BENITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They killed his son in August. The villagers did. Because of a land dispute. Cleo looks at him, moved.

dialogues.speaker: BENITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got life?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Sure...

dialogues.speaker: BENITA
dialogues.text: I mean liquor.  70.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Benita pours her a shot of moonshine.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I'd rather just have a little pulque.

dialogues.speaker: BENITA
dialogues.text: That's the spirit! She pours pulque into a jar and hands it to Cleo. The two toast.

dialogues.speaker: BENITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here’s to a beautiful 1971 and to your baby’s health!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO AND BENITA
dialogues.text: Cheers! Benita takes the jar to her lips and Cleo draws her pulqu close to hers when Gloria trips dancing her quebradita an bumps into Cleo. Before even touching her lips, the pulque jar falls to th ground and shatters into a million pieces.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Sorry, manita!

dialogues.speaker: BENITA
dialogues.text: No sweat. You dance, we got plenty more where that came from! She pours pulque into a new jar. Gloria keeps dancing. Cl holds the other pulque but looks worriedly down at the shattered jar on the floor. INT. —- INTERNAL PATIO - STAIRS - HACIENDA - NIGHT Cleo exits the kitchen. She’s a little tipsy. The patio i empty except for the dogs who follow her until she reache the stairs that lead up to - EXT. — CORRIDOR - HACIENDA - NIGHT Cleo walks down the candle-lit corridor and back into the living room where “Mummy Blues” is playing on the stereo. sees a silhouette resting on the balustrade: it’s Sefiora Sofia.  71.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Alejandro Matos comes out of the parlour and comes close Sofia, hugging her from behind. Sofia reacts, turning aro in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Alejandro tries to kiss her, but she rejects him.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ALEJANDRO MATOS
dialogues.text: Come, now... You know you want to... Sofia struggles to free herself.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: No, Alex! Leave me alone! You’re drunk! She pushes him. Alejandro holds his hands up, resentful a resigned -

dialogues.speaker: DR. ALEJANDRO MATOS
dialogues.text: Fine. Fine! I just wanted to comfort you, but... He begins to walk back into the parlour. DR. ALEJANDRO MATOS (CONT’D) It’s not even like you’re that hot, comadre... Sefiora Sofia leans into the balustrade, confused and agitated. She looks in Cleo’s direction, but Cleo hides behind a column. Sefiora Sofia walks back into the parlour, Cleo waits for to leave before coming out of her hiding spot. She leans the balustrade and looks out at the night. When her eyes get used to the darkness, she can see the darker silhouettes of the trees in front of a sky that se to be lit from within. The cricket song melts into “Mummy Blues”, ending on a scratch, and the accordion which seems to be playing a mazurca. The wind blows softly. Through the darkness in the woods, a pale light appears, almost blending into the night. Cleo watches in fascinati  72.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Shocking Blue’s “Venus” starts to play. The dogs star barking. The shining starts to spread out in a warm, attractive pulsing, like a will o’ the wisp or an apparition. Cleo watches, hypnotized. But what started off as a soft begins to rip through the night in an intense gleam that dances in the trees. The barks become more insistent. Someone screams -

dialogues.speaker: SCREAMING
dialogues.text: Fire! Fire! In the woods! A racket. More screaming. More barking. In the garden, Celso runs, carrying a bucket. Other worke follow after him, carrying buckets and pots overflowing w water. They run towards the woods in flames. EXT -— SMALL CLEARING IN THE WOODS - HACIENDA - NIGHT The giant puddle reflects the flames dancing over the roc on the ground. The fire licks the trees and spreads into branches. The flames push forward, devouring the clearing grass, th very same place where just this afternoon they were all shooting. Celso runs to the fire and empties out his bucket. The workers do the same. They come back for more water and cr paths with yet other workers carrying various containers. Dr. José arrives carrying two buckets, followed by Ricard Edwards, with one. Further behind, Dr. Alejandro Matos an Leslie carry a heavy washbasin. Gloria, Flor, Yola and Cleo all bring their containers. E the kids. Everyone runs, comes, goes... the dogs keep the distance. A human chain starts to form: buckets pass from hand to h everyone trying to put out the fire. The pagan monster with his drink in hand arrives. He look his watch -  73.

dialogues.speaker: OVE
dialogues.text: (In English) 23...22...21...20...19...18...17... The monster takes off his mask, revealing a sweaty and dr Ove -
The human chain begins to work efficiently. Pepe even put out a few blades of glass with his little cup.

dialogues.speaker: OVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: eT Gee See dbe ee Sec e2ecelece

dialogues.speaker: HAPPY NEW YEAR
dialogues.text: But no one pays attention. Everyone is working, trying to control the fire.

dialogues.speaker: OVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Happy New year! Ove starts singing in Norwegian. It’s an emotional Nyttar song.

dialogues.speaker: OVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pkfmsll apdkfn alosnnm... The children go to the puddle and fill up their little containers. The dogs follow them, splashing. The reflecti is disarticulated in waves that bump into each other.

dialogues.speaker: OVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pkfmsll apdkfn alosnnm... Ove sings with conviction. His eyes fill with tears. Friday, January lst, 1971.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dew makes the woods shine, though they’re still dark and smoking. The first rays of the new year sun filter throug the trees. Four folding chairs rest the middle of the clearing, char  74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Iztaccihuatl sleeps, immense, behind the hills and du crops. The afternoon light filters through rain-leaden clouds. A group of children run and explore. Tofio, Pepe de la Barcena, Ricky, Paco, Rodri, Alex and Eduardo lead the front throwing each other football passe Paco, Rodri, and Alex chase after chameleons in the furro Lola and Clau walk next to them. Vero, Sofi, Gerardo, And and July are further back. Pepe and Andy walk with Yola. Cleo walks with Benita. The dogs run everywhere. Alex cha after a chameleon, Rodri and Paco follow.

dialogues.speaker: BENITA
dialogues.text: Don’t run too far. We’ll just reach to the outskirts and come back! Paco stops-—

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: What skirts?

dialogues.speaker: BENITA
dialogues.text: The hillside. Paco laughs.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: You mean the hill has skirts?

dialogues.speaker: BENITA
dialogues.text: The outskirts... well, the slopes then!

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Alex, the hill has a skirt! Alex stops.

dialogues.speaker: PACO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If we lean over we’ll be able to see its panties. Paco pretends to lean and Alex does the same. Lola and Cl catch up to them -

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDIA
dialogues.text: What are you guys doing?  75.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Looking up the hill’s skirts to see its panties.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Hills don’t have underwear. Paco leans under her and lifts up her miniskirt.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: And neither do you! Lola screams and pats down her skirt -—

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Asshole!

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Ooooooh! Alex lifts up Clau’s dress. She screams.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Alex! Paco! Leave the girls alone! The boys run, amused. Cleo and Benita stop. A gust of wind conjures dust devils low thunder rumbles and rain falls in the distance. Cleo looks at the landscape dreamily. Her hands rest on h belly.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: It’s like my village. Without the mountain, of course, but it looks just like this... She enjoys the moment while she rubs her belly. She close her eyes -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is how it sounds... The church bells ringing and the bleating of goats get lo in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just like this... She breathes. Breathes deep. She smiles -  76.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is how it smells... Cleo is somewhere else. Friday, January 29, 1971.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The Valiant is parked in front of the house, next to the Galaxie 500. The Valiant overflows with the children. One more comes o Tofio’s friend, BETO PARDO, 12, with glasses and good-boy looks. He’s come for lunch. Paco shows off the black Galaxie, its scrapes and bent moldings recently repaired -—

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Look, they fixed it all up. Just like new, right? Beto barely looks at it. He keeps going and goes into the house after Tofo.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Cleo’s belly is starting to show. She cuts Pepe’s meat. Sefiora Teresa eats in silence. The children talk while t eat -

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: The Cowboys won only because Baltimore was overconfident.

dialogues.speaker: BETO
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? We scored three touchdowns in the second half. One after the other! Sefiora Sofia comes down the stairs and into the breakfas room.  77.

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: I’m telling you. Baltimore was overconfident. How can you root for the Cowboys?

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: I like the Cowboy’s cheerleaders. In my school...

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Who cares about cheerleaders? Sefiora Sofia comes into the breakfast room. Her face is drawn. Sefiora Teresa looks at her, worried.

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: Ma? Can Beto and I go to the movies? Sefiora Sofia is absent -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: What are you going to see?

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: The Red Tent, at The Americas theater.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: I want to go too!

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: No, just Beto and me.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: Get yourself your own friends!

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: I want to go to the movies too!

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: I said no! It’s just me and Beto. Sefiora Sofia explodes -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Either everyone goes or no one goes!  78.

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: They can go to a different movie!

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: I want to go to Las Americas!

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: You don’t even know what The Red Tent is!

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: I said, either everyone goes or no one goes! The telephone rings, Sefiora Sofia gets up and walks to t hall to answer -

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: It’s not fair! Sefiora Sofia comes back -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: If you don’t like it you can go live somewhere else! She walks over to pick up the phone, leaving Tofio furiou Paco smiles impertinently.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Is it a cartoon? Sefiora Sofia answers -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Hello? Oh, yes, hold on a minute... She calls to the breakfast room - SENORA SOF{A (CONT’D) Cleo! I’m going to get this upstairs, would you mind hanging up here! She goes upstairs. Cleo walks to the phone and she hears Sefiora Sofia calling -  79.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There...! Cleo is about to hang up the phone when she overhears...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: How are you feeling, comadre? Cleo hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone’s ready to go to the movies. Sefiora Teresa is g too, because she worries and because she loves going to t movies. She calls up to the children -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA
dialogues.text: We're late! You coming down or what? Paco and Sofi are already by her side.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Let them stay. Let’s go...

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA
dialogues.text: We're leaving! Sefiora Teresa goes out to the Patio with Cleo, Paco, Sof Pepe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group reaches the street entrance and Sefiora Teresa the door. Borras takes advantage of the situation to run despite Cleo and Paco’s attempts to stop him. Paco runs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He chases the dog down and drags him back into the house where the group is waiting outside the door. Paco leaves the dog inside and is about to close the door when Toho and Beto come out.

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: What are you waiting for?  80.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The two hurry up to the corner heading towards Insurgente Everyone follows them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tofo and Beto are at the front. Cleo and Sefiora Teresa l after Sofi and Pepe who is talking to Paco about planes.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: ..-Braniff planes may be different colors but they’re all 727s... They're on Tepic street, near Insurgentes when Tofio and take off in a well planned strategy.

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: See you at the movies! The pair run off.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA
dialogues.text: Tofno! Seflora Teresa asks Cleo to follow them. Cleo embarks on her mission. She hurries without losing T and Beto from sight, their two little mischievous figures already half a block away. They ring doorbells and run aw Cleo shortens the distance with each step, getting closer but not too close. And so, she follows them. When they reach Insurgentes the boys run off, and turn, disappearing at the corner. Cleo hurries and turns the co to - EXT. —- INSURGENTES AVENUE - LAS AMERICAS CINEMA —- DUSK Cleo reaches the bustling avenue, brimming with its early Friday night energy. People walk in all directions and th street lights, the cars, the shop windows and the ads are lighting up.  81.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She sees people crossing to the other side of Insurgentes where the marquee announces Melody, but she doesn’t see t boys. She worries and walks to the following corner, searching. She's almost made it to the newspaper stand in the next corner when she turns and looks to -

dialogues.speaker: THE OTHER SIDE OF INSURGENTES
dialogues.text: And there, amongst the crowd coming out of the theater an spilling onto the sidewalk, she sees Sefior Antonio. He l light and happy and dances a silly step to the great deli and laughter of the YOUNG WOMAN who holds his hand. And that’s when she also finally spots Beto, hiding on on side of the news stand, lost in the pages of Caballero me magazine. Beyond, Tofio is also holding a magazine, but he’s not lo at the naked women in its pages. He’s looking at the othe side of the street: people are coming out of the theater his dad is playing Fred Astaire to a Ginger Rogers that i not his mother. In his silly dance move, Sefior Antonio trips with an OLD COUPLE who is annoyed. Sefior Antonio and the young woman laugh and hurry off.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER COUPLE
dialogues.text: So rude...! Sefior Antonio stops, turns and to sprays bullets at the couple with his make believe machine gun, escaping with t young woman, Bonnie & Clyde, hand in hand. Wednesday, March 24th, 1971.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT
dialogues.text: Cleo’s riding a bus full of people. EXT. — DIRT AVENUE - CIUDAD NEZAHUALCOYOTL - DAY Cleo climbs down the bus, her six-month belly is obvious the contrast with the Roma neighborhood is evident too -  82.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The dirt avenue is flanked by large electric towers and riddled with pot holes where stagnant water pools. The houses are made of cement brick, corrugated cardboard asbestos sheets. There’s lots of trash and plastic. Cleo shows a piece of paper to a PEDESTRIAN who points to street up the avenue. Cleo heads up the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleo walks on. Misery is palpable, there are children and stray dogs everywhere and a stream of raw sewage running the street. Different music booms out of each house. Three dogs block her way and bark. Cleo crouches, pretend to get a rock and the dogs run off. She reaches a house and double-checks the address on her paper. She comes to the door and knocks. Impertinent dogs answer her knocking next to the entrance Cleo knocks again as the door opens. It’s Ramén. INT/EXT — DATSUN - OCEANIA AVE - DAY Cleo rides alone in the back seat. In front, Ramén is in driver's seat, and his friend CANCHAS, is in the passenge seat, smoking pot. He gives the joint to Ramén, who takes drag and passes it to Cleo, who refuses.

dialogues.speaker: NEXT TO THE FIELD -
dialogues.text: About a hundred young men in uniformed t-shirts and tenni shoes are in resting position, supervised by three instructors with martial airs, pants and sweat-shirts. They pay attention to a man in sweat pants and a sleevele shirt who makes an exercise demonstration -  83.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The man does push-ups with his index finger only. A young man standing next to Cleo says with admiration -

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: It’s Zovek.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: (in disbelief) No...! Zovek?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Look at ‘im...

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Is that really professor Zovek?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: He’s done over a hundred push ups by now!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: What? Does he always come here?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: No, not always, but sometimes he comes to train them. PROFESSOR ZOVEK counts to 150, pushes hard on his fingers in one swift move is on his feet, crossing his wrists ove his head. The young men applaud.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR ZOVEK
dialogues.text: You too can be a Kombateka! Every human being holds great potential he must develop through physical conditioning and through mental and spiritual evolution. Zovek walks amongst them. PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) You too can develop your potential. But don’t expect any miracles, the only miracle lies in your own will. Zovek stops -  84.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) This is why mental development is the true motor of physical development. He stretches his arms, taking his audience in - PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) And next up... an act! A strip of bandage hangs from one of his hands, swaying i the dusty breeze - ON THE EDGE OF THE FIELD -— Cleo and the small audience call out in surprise -

dialogues.speaker: SMALL AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Ooooooh! Zovek exclaims -

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR ZOVEK
dialogues.text: This is a routine that requires absolute physical condition! Only martial arts masters and a few great athletes can master it! Professor Zovek extends the bandage to a YOUTH in the fir row. PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) Yes... You... please bandage my eyes. The youth walks up shyly to Professor Zovek and takes the bandage, starts to bandage his eyes - PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) Make sure they’re totally covered. You’ve got plenty of bandage there. They youth has completely covered Professor Zovek’s eyes. PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) Thank you, you may return to your place. The youth walks back to his spot.  85. PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) And now...! Professor Zovek flexes his biceps and puts the fingers in both of his hands together in a diamond shape over his he He inhales deeply and - PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) (Exhaling) Huuuuuuuh! He is quiet. The young people look on, expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE EDGE OF THE FIELD -
dialogues.text: Cleo and the small audience look on in awe. Professor Zovek is standing, motionless, with his diamond over his head and slowly, very slowly starts to lift his foot. Time has stopped. The left foot lifts up, folding at the knee until the thi is at a 45 degree angle, and he remains motionless in tha position. The young people await in confusion for something to happ

dialogues.speaker: AT THE EDGE OF THE FIELD -
dialogues.text: Cleo and the small audience are also waiting, a boy crouc down. Professor Zovek continues on, motionless - PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) Are you disappointed? Were you expecting me to lift a jet or an elephant? The audience laughs. PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) You are witnessing an incredible feat! You don’t believe me? Try it. Professor Zovek talks but remains motionless - PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) Just close your eyes and lift up a foot. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) You don’t have to lift your leg to a forty-five degree angle like me or put your arms up. Just close your eyes and lift a foot. IN THE ROWS -— The young men close their eyes and try lifting one foot. quickly lose their balance. The instructors also try it without succeeding.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE EDGE OF THE FIELD -
dialogues.text: Cleo and the small audience also tries it out, some child lasts a little longer but they all fail. Professor Zovek explains -— PROFESSOR ZOVEK (CONT’D) True mental preparation is the path to physical realization. The small audience begins to notice that - Cleo is on one foot, forming a diamond with her fingers o her head. Her eyes closed, placid.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A trainer blows his whistle and the formation breaks up. young men pick up their belongings at the edge of the fie and walk over to the parking lot. Cleo watches them walk by, and in a small group she finds Fermin, who walks talking, animated. Cleo wants to call him, but is anxiously silent. Fermin a his group walk right past her. Cleo finally calls to him -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Fermin! Perhaps a little too loud. Fermin turns and when he sees he stops. Others in his group stop with him

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: What’s up my Cleo?  87.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Can you talk for a minute? The group surrounding Fermin make fun of him -

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: Wooococ00000000! Fermin smiles and walks towards Cleo gesturing good bye t his group. Cleo and Fermin walk one toward the other in the emptying lot.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BACKGROUND -
dialogues.text: An Eastern Airlines Boeing 727 takes off and flies over t couple approaching in the middle of the lot.

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: Long time no see, Cleo!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Hi, Fermin... They meet and kiss hello.

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: What are you doing around these parts?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Well, I have left you so many messages and I’ve been looking for you but I can never find you so... Fermin starts heading toward the parking lot -

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry my Cleo, but the training got real hard core and they even brought in a gringo trainer and another one from Korea. Well, the American had been here already, but the Korean one is new.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Is it for the Olympics?  88.

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: Something like that. Who told you I was here? Cleo hesitates -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: It’s just that a neighbor's brother in law trains with you so...

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: (interrupting) It was Ramon, right?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: No, no, no! Fermin stops -—

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: Son of a... Fucking Ramén. I’11 get him when I see him - He makes some pretend impressive aikido movements -

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jodan Tsuki!... Chudan Tsuki!... Mae Geril... Flash blows, precise kicks and body contact with the air.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: It’s just that... I’m with child... Fermin stops mid-punch. He keeps walking to the parking l

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: What’s it to me? Cleo follows him -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Well, the little one’s yours. Fermin walks faster.

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: No fucking way!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: But it is, Fermin!  89.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fermin stops completely and turns to Cleo -

dialogues.speaker: FERMIN
dialogues.text: I told you already, there’s no fucking way! So if you don’t want me to fuck you up real bad, you and your “little one” too, don’t ever fucking say it again and don’t ever come looking for me again! He does some aikido movements culminating in a mortal blo Cleo, stopping less than half an inch from her face and t walks off. FERMIN (CONT’D) Fucking cunt! He leaves Cleo alone in the empty lot. Friday, May 14th, 1971.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Borras barks like crazy. Cleo holds his collar but is los her own sadness. Her almost-eight-month belly is very lar The old man with the oranges puts three more oranges in t crate on the floor. It’s almost full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man gets up and Adela pays him with a crumpled 20 peso bill. Further back, Cleo holds on to Borras, who tries to lunge the old man with each bark. The old man slowly carries the immense sack of oranges an puts it on his back. He starts walking towards -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Cleo is holding Borras who pushes up on his hind le to attack the old man who walks past them on his way to t street.  90.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The old man is halfway down the patio when Borras tugs ha surprising Cleo, who is lost in thought and lets go. Borras runs down to the old man who hurries to the door a feels the dog coming. Borras chases him.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Borras! Borras lunges at the old man and sinks his teeth into the enormous sack. Dozens of oranges fall out rolling all over the patio. The old man lets go of the sack and runs to the door whil Borras is trying to finish off the sack. Cleo runs up to Borras on the orange-covered floor. The o man is almost at the door when the dog realizes this and after him. The old man reaches the door and opens. Borras is about t sink in his teeth when the old man exits and shuts the do Borras can’t stop and smashes against the door. Cleo is standing in the middle of the patio, surrounded b ocean of oranges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The midday light bounces off the patio walls and slides i through the great windows, softly caressing the modern mahogany table. Cleo polishes the surface with a rag. She rubs the rag ov and over the same spot, as if she wanted to wipe her own reflection. The house is quiet. Only the rumor of a conversation is heard. The phone cable extending all the way into the bathroom under the stairs disappears inside the door. Sefiora Sofia is inside, talking. Her voice echoes in the small space and filters though the doors. Only a few word can be clearly heard. Paco comes down the stairs slowly. Stopping in the middle leans over the railway, trying to hear better. Cleo keeps polishing the same area of the table and final realizes Paco is coming down the stairs.  91.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Paco’s in the hall and walks slowly to the bathroom door, leaning on the wall next to it. Cleo stops wiping her reflection and sees Paco, who - Slides and sits down on the floor. He leans against the w and tries to move his ear closer to the door. From the dining room, Cleo shoos him away, gesturing, but Paco ignores her, concentrated on listening to the conversation distorted by the bathroom echo and muffled b the door.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: ..-he wrote them letters from so- called Vancouver... Cleo walks up to Paco, gesturing. When she reaches the ha she stops at a respectful distance from the bathroom and conversation. She stops and shakes her rag vigorously, calling Paco.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: ..-he doesn’t even have enough of a pair to tell the children... He sees her but shakes his head no repeatedly. Cleo comes few steps closer, still keeping her distance, and speaks mouthing the words but almost without a single sound.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: (articulating) G-e-t o-u-t- o-f h-e-r-e Paco is about to shake his head no but a cry punctures th echoes and the walls - a deep desperate wail. Paco and Cleo freeze, scared, when suddenly - The bathroom door opens and Sefiora Sofia comes out, carr the phone. She sees Paco running away and grabs him -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: And you? What are you spying on?... Her face is gaunt from crying, from all the pain and frustration that explode in a - Giant slap that throws Paco down on the floor. Sefiora Sofia immediately realizes what she’s done and crouches down next to her son, holding him, crying -  92.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOF
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I’m sorry, Paco! Why were you eavesdropping? Why were you eavesdropping? The two of them cry on the floor, Sefiora Sofia sees Cleo only a few steps away -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOF
dialogues.text: And you! Why did you let him? She hugs Paco tightly - SENORA SOF{A (CONT’D) Don’t say anything to your brothers and sisters. Don’t say a thing. Promise me... Promise... To the side, Cleo is motionless, wishing she could join i the hugging and the crying. INT. - SOFI AND PEPE’S ROOM - TEPEJI 21- DUSK Cleo brushes Sofi’s hair. They’re sitting on the bed. Sof reads a letter. Cleo is lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: It has so many drawings. Look, I think this little girl is me and I think this is my daddy... The letter is done exclusively in blue ink drawings with color or highlights.

dialogues.speaker: SOFI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And this is a heart, look, with an S for Sofi and a P for Papa... and this here is a dog... or is ita fish? Pepe comes in and sits down next to them, leaning over to the letter.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s a dolphin, I think?

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: A dolphin? No. It’s like a doggie...  93.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: It’s a seal! In the fourth letter my dad sent Paco, he said he can see the ocean from his hotel room and that there are a lot of seals. Sofi considers the drawing -

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Yes. It’s a seal! Like the ones in his hotel!

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: You had said dolphin. It looks nothing like a dolphin!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: So it’s not a dolphin? What do you think it is? Sofi and Pepe answer in a chorus -

dialogues.speaker: SOFI AND PEPE
dialogues.text: A seal! And they also laugh in chorus. Distracted by her own sadn Cleo turns to Pepe and does a surprise tickle attack, prolonging the laughter. When they’ve calmed down, Pepe is lying on the bed and fi his eyes on Cleo.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: What you looking at?

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: When’s your baby coming out? Sadness washes over Cleo again -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Next month.

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: It is a girl?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Oh, please let it be a girl! Pleeeease! What’s her name?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: If it’s a girl can her name be Tabitha like Bewitched?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: (Absently) Maybe... Pepe gets up and looks at her, serious.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: And will she live here?

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: If she’s a girl yes!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Would you like her to live here?

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: No way! Yuck! Cleo smiles, trying to hide her pain. She changes the top

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Let’s see! Put your pajamas on! Saturday, May 15th, 1971. INT. - SENORA SOFIA’S ROOM - TEPEJI 21- DAY The room glows softly in the light that filters in throug the curtains. Cleo folds freshly washed clothes in the closet drawers. she opens one she looks down at Sefior Antonio’s underwea She can hear the children fighting downstairs.  95.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cleo closes the drawer. She looks at the men’s suits hang The yelling grows more intense and in the middle, Sefiora Teresa —

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Children! Stop it, Tofio! Stop! Sofi comes running into the room.

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Cleo! Tofio and Paco are fighting! Cleo comes out to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With her 8-month belly, Cleo slowly goes down the stairs Sofi. When they come down they see -

dialogues.speaker: IN THE HALL-
dialogues.text: Tofio who is holding Paco by the hairs. Paco is screaming furiously and attempting to kick Tofio. Sefiora Teresa is in the living room yelling at the boys. is standing, paralyzed, next to her.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA
dialogues.text: Stop it! Now! But Paco manages to free himself and hits Tofio on the fa Tofio grabs his arms.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STAIRCASE -
dialogues.text: Cleo stops. Sofi takes her hand -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Boys! IN THE HALL -— Paco spits in Tofio’s face, leaving him space to give him good slap.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA
dialogues.text: Tofno! And Paco throws himself against Tofio once again, while T speedily escapes.  96.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STAIRCASE -
dialogues.text: Cleo is still walking down.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Boys! I’m going to tell your mom when she comes back! IN THE HALL -— The boys don’t pay any attention to her at all. Paco take trinket from the table, a stone egg, and -

dialogues.speaker: HE THROWS IT TO TONO -
dialogues.text: It flies straight to his head.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA
dialogues.text: Paco! Tofio ducks just as the speedy egg projectile, flies exac over where his face was, following its trajectory through open doors, out the patio and - CRASHING against the door of the Valiant, parked just outside. Sefiora Teresa runs towards Paco and grabs him hard, shak him -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing! Paco!

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: He hit me first!

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: Because you pushed me! Cleo walks into the hall with Sofi, towards the living ro

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA
dialogues.text: How could you throw that thing!? You could have killed your brother! Paco stops wrestling, remorseful. Cleo comes to Pepe, hug him and Sofi is with her. Sefiora Teresa lets go of Paco

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA
dialogues.text: You could have killed him!  97.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Scared, Tono looks at the car door where the egg has left enormous dent in the metal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is quiet again. Cleo washes dishes. Adela puts them away on the shelves.

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: You head up, manita, I'll finish up here... The Galaxie 500 honks its horn - Ta-ta Ta-ta Ta-ta Ta-taaaaaaaa! ADELA (CONT’D) I’ll go. Adela goes out the small patio and to the patio. Cleo wal to the breakfast room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleo walks across the breakfast room and the dining room goes out to the hall. She peeks out the door that opens t the patio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ta-ta! Ta-ta! Ta-taaaaaaaa! Adela walks to the street door, lit from the outside by t car's headlights. Ta-ta! Ta-ta! Ta-taaaaaaaa! Adela opens the door, revealing - The mighty Galaxie 500 headlights lighting the patio. The car pulls in slowly but - Kkkkkkkjj355355k! Its left side scratches against the door frame.  98.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The car brakes and moves back a couple of inches. Adjusts trajectory and pulls forward again - Krrrrrrajjjj! Now its right side hits the frame. The car stops and veers its wheels left. Moves forward. Kkkjjjjjkkk! The left molding catches the frame and begins to bend. Th car stops. Backs up. Goes forward again and now the right side molding is the that’s caught. The car stops. Backs up. It starts forward again and the right side molding is rip from the metal, but now the car doesn’t stop. It just hea straight in, ripping the entire left side molding too. It adjusts its course once more. The side mirror catches is ripped off. The Galaxie 500 stops only momentarily to follow its cour with even greater conviction, hitting and denting both si its molding bent in strange shapes. Finally, the Galaxie stops in front of the door that open the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleo is next to the patio door. Outside - The Galaxie door opens and Sefiora Sofia comes out. She stumbles as she walks and comes into the house without closing the car door. She is obviously drunk. Cleo moves aside to let her through. Sefiora Sofia looks her, amused -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: We're alone. Always. Even though they say we aren’t. She laughs and Cleo looks at her, confused.  99.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sefiora Sofia walks on and staggers up the stairs. Thursday, June 10th, 1971.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT
dialogues.text: Ignacio is driving. Cleo is sitting in the front and Sefi Teresa rides behind, alone. They drive slowly in heavy traffic. A parked car tries to come out onto the street. Ignacio s and lets it through -

dialogues.speaker: IGNACIO
dialogues.text: Maybe if we park over here, far away, because there’s a student protest. There’s a bustle of young people on the sidewalks and wal up the street. Some carry pickets and painted slogans.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA
dialogues.text: I hope they don’t get them again... The parked car frees up a space and Ignacio tries to park EXT. — STREET NEAR MEXICO-TACUBA - AFTERNOON The Valiant parks, Sefiora Teresa and Cleo come out with Ignacio accompanying them. Cleaning trucks are parked alo the block. They walk amongst the students heading up the street to t corner which is surveilled by police vehicles, and they p in front of a group of young men dressed in T-shirts, waiting. EXT. -— CALZADA MEXICO-TACUBA - AFTERNOON Ignacio accompanies Teresa and Cleo, who walk slowly. Cle account of her belly, and Sefora Teresa due to her limp. storefront metallic curtains are all shut. They walk in front of a long row of riot police trucks, l of police officers while a group of young men carrying ba canes gathers at the corner.  100. They reach Calzada México - Tacuba and it’s closed off. T beginning of an enormous march passes next to them, walki from north to south on the Avenue. Sefiora Teresa, Cleo and Ignacio are forced to cross in t middle of the march. They melt in with the crowd - some h pickets, others sing slogans. They manage to make it to the other side of the avenue an head towards the entrance of a building advertising a furniture store on the second floor, letters painted on i windows. Sefiora Teresa and Cleo walk in. Ignacio waits outside. INT. — FURNITURE STORE - CALZADA MEXICO TACUBA - AFTERNOO The afternoon sun lights the MUEBLERIA sign painted all a the windows, staining the floor with its upside-down lett A handful of clients walks around the store, which sells cheap and functional furniture. The din of the march fill the place with chanting and slogans. Cleo and Sefiora Teresa walk through the nursery section. see a crib -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA
dialogues.text: You like that one?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: It’s so beautiful. Sefiora Teresa sees the price tag and calls a YOUNG SALES over. She comes immediately -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA
dialogues.text: What’s your best price on this crib. The saleswoman looks at the tag.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA TERESA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: With my faithful old time customer discount, eh?

dialogues.speaker: SALESWOMAN
dialogues.text: Let me ask the manager. The saleswoman walks up to the counter. The outside din t into a chorus roar of terrified screams. It is five o’ seven p.m.  101.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ignacio runs through the door, panic in his eyes. Everyon the store looks at him, confused. The outside roar intensifies. Ignacio runs to the window looks out. Other clients do the same. Terror in their eye Cleo and Sefiora Teresa slowly approach and they join Ign to look out the window -

dialogues.speaker: CALZADA MEXICO
dialogues.text: The giant line of students is attacked frontally by more 100 young men in tennis hoes, T-shirts and short haircuts armed with 6 foot bamboo canes, clubs and metal rods administering electric shocks. They are the HALCONES. The paramilitary group attacks furiously. The multitude runs, but more Halcones have surrounded the from the back and come out of the surrounding streets. Shots are heard and a cloud of gunpowder begins to form. People fall. Women, old men. Children. INSIDE THE FURNITURE STORE — Steps can be heard up and down the staircase and a STUDEN comes in, bleeding from the head. He’s not even 20 years The clients cry out in alarm. The student looks at them imploringly and, scared, he turns to hear the noise in th staircase. The STORE MANAGER signals for him to come in quickly and calls the young saleswoman over.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Put him in the closet. The young woman rushes the student in to the closet at th back of the store, when - Three HALCONES appear. People are terrified. A woman starts crying. Ignacio walk protectively in front of Cleo and Sefiora Teresa. The Halcones see the young woman closing the closet door. head over, one stays in the middle of the store, controll the people.  102.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The young woman places her body in front of the closet do The first Halcén hits her and throws her on the floor, op the door and the second Halcén - SHOOTS THREE TIMES. The student falls out of the closet, and to the floor whe THE HALCON SHOOTS HIM TWO MORE TIMES. People scream and the Halcén at the rearguard surveils th menacingly. Shielded by Ignacio, Cleo sees the Halcdén at the reargua The Halcén also sees her. THEY RECOGNIZE EACH OTHER. It’s Fermin. Cleo starts hyperventilating. The two other Halcones begin retreating and Fermin follow them. The three leave the store. Cleo watches them go. Her breathing is fast. A puddle forms at her feet. Her water has broken.

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Ignacio holds Cleo and helps her walk. Sefiora Teresa wal next to them. Terrified people run in all directions. Shots are fired a there is a lot of smoke in the air. Students run towards them, terrified, chased after by Halcones with bamboo sticks. Ignacio pulls Cleo to the entrance of a Vecindad, taking shelter and Sefora Teresa follows after them. In front of them, on the street, the Halcones catch up wi student and beat him to a pulp. They keep going. Ignacio peeks out at the street, pulls Cleo out and they leave the doorway to continue on their way. Sefiora Teres follows after them.  103.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They walk down Mexico - Tacuba. On the ground, men, women old and young, lie dead. Some surrounded by pools of bloo A YOUNG WOMAN cries kneeling on the floor. She holds a yo man’s head. Halcones come up and beat her violently. INT/EXT - ‘64 VALIANT - STREET- AFTERNOON At the wheel, Ignacio weaves through traffic finding any empty spot he can slide into.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Aaaaaaaaaaaahhhhhhhggggg! In the back seat, Cleo suffers contractions. Next to her, Seflora Teresa holds her hand.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The ‘64 Valiant rushes down Cuauhtemoc Avenue and turns i the Medical Center entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The building and ramp lights are on against the purple sk wanting to become night. Ignacio helps Cleo walk. Sefiora Teresa, slower, follows behind. On the esplanade, pregnant woman walk around, some accompanied, waiting for their imminent deliveries. Ignacio and Cleo walk into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaos. Pregnant woman walk around the lobby while some wait with their family members in the waiting room. Names are calle the loudspeaker and pregnant women are admitted. CRIES AND MOANS from women going through contractions. In the reception, nurses efficiently tend to the long lin patients.  104.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ignacio enters the lobby holding Cleo. They immediately w to the reception area. When they arrive, he tells Cleo -

dialogues.speaker: IGNACIO
dialogues.text: Wait for me here. Just a sec. He leaves Cleo and tries to talk to a hurried NURSE -

dialogues.speaker: IGNACIO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Excuse me... But the nurse doesn’t pause, she only points -

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Line is over there... Ignacio sees the line and Cleo has another contraction, standing.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaahhhaa! Ignacio yells out to make himself heard on top of the rac of questions, orders, complaints and cries -

dialogues.speaker: IGNACIO
dialogues.text: (screaming) Doctor Vélez! Doctor Vélez! No one seems to hear him. Ignacio insists -

dialogues.speaker: IGNACIO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (screaming) Doctor Vélez! Doctor Vélez! Doctor Vélez comes in through the medical team and patien door. She hurries to Ignacio -

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ
dialogues.text: Here, here, here.... Ignacio takes her to Cleo while Doctor Vélez lifts an arm emphatically calls out -

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nurse! Nurse! A nurse runs to them, pushing a wheelchair. Sefiora Teres finally arrived. She is completely breathless. Doctora Vélez reaches Cleo-  105.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ
dialogues.text: Hi, Cleo. How are you feeling? Cleo looks at her: fear is her only answer. The nurse com in and helps Cleo sit down on the wheelchair. Ignacio hel too.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll take it from here. You can wait out there. Rosary in hand, Sefora Teresa and Ignacio look at Cleo be wheeled off through the door leading to -

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Cleo is in the wheelchair, scared. She is surrounded by Doctor Vélez and the nurses. They reach the elevators and wait. The elevator doors open and they walk in. The doors are a to close when Sefior Antonio, dressed in his white coat, up to them and goes in as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors close.

dialogues.speaker: SENOR ANTONIO
dialogues.text: Hi Cleo, how are you feeling? Cleo looks at him, surprised -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Doctor...! Sefior Antonio tries to encourage her -

dialogues.speaker: SENOR ANTONIO
dialogues.text: You're in good hands... How many babies have you delivered, Doctor Vélez? Doctor Vélez smiles -

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ
dialogues.text: Hundreds! Cleo has a strong contraction -  106.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Aaaahhhhggg! Sefior Antonio holds her hand and leans down to bring his closer to Cleo’s -

dialogues.speaker: SENOR ANTONIO
dialogues.text: Breathe Cleo... Like this... Sefior Antonio begins inhaling and exhaling and blowing. tries to imitate him by looking at his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator opens its doors and Cleo’s chair is wheeled by the nurses. The sixth floor has no windows. They pass the nurse station and reach the door that leads the Birthing room. Sefior Antonio leans in to Cleo -

dialogues.speaker: SENOR ANTONIO
dialogues.text: Doctor Vélez will only let me come up to this point.... Doctor Vélez interrupts -

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ
dialogues.text: Don’t mind me. Come in if you like.

dialogues.speaker: SENOR ANTONIO
dialogues.text: No, uh... I have a patient... His excuse hangs in the air and he puts a hand over Cleo’ shoulder -

dialogues.speaker: SENOR ANTONIO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're going to be just fine, Cleo... And he scurries down the hallway. Frightened and confused Cleo has barely registered the exchange. The nurses wheel her into -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cubicle, separated from other cubicles by a curtain and screens, the gynecological bed is in the middle. The nurs help Cleo to get up and out of the wheelchair -  107.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ
dialogues.text: Take off all your clothes and put on this gown, OK? Cleo undresses. She doesn’t have much privacy and, behind poorly closed curtains she can see other women being examined. Doctor Vélez asks her questions to which she answers in confusion.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When did you last menstruate?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: September?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ
dialogues.text: Do you have a due date?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: June 21st...

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ
dialogues.text: Were there any complications during the pregnancy? Scared, Cleo shakes her head no.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How long ago did your water break?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: About an hour and a half ago. We couldn’t get out of where we were and...

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ
dialogues.text: Was it clear?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ
dialogues.text: The water. Was it transparent?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: No. A little thick. Like soup. Cleo is about to close her gown when she suffers a very painful contraction. Doctor Vélez orders -  108.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTORA VELEZ
dialogues.text: Don’t push Cleo, blow. Help her get on the bed... The nurses help Cleo lie down on the gynecological bed. Doctor Vélez touches the top of her belly -

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ
dialogues.text: Check dilation. A RESIDENT examines her and declares

dialogues.speaker: RESIDENT
dialogues.text: Seven or eight centimeters...

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ
dialogues.text: Frequency? The RESIDENT checks on the cardiac rhythm with a Pinard stethoscope while a nurse fills out papers.

dialogues.speaker: RESIDENT
dialogues.text: I can’t hear the foetal focus...

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Blow, ma’am!

dialogues.speaker: RESIDENT
dialogues.text: She’s full. She’s in second plane... expulsive with full dilation and there is four cross meconium and asystole. Doctor Vélez gives a round of instructions -

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ
dialogues.text: Plug in mixed solution at 5% and wheel her into Labor immediately. Alert pediatrics. Prepare a laryngoscope, reanimation equipment and an ambu. The nurses quickly bring a gurney up to the gynecological table. The resident asks Cleo -

dialogues.speaker: RESIDENT
dialogues.text: Can you climb onto the gurney for me?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ
dialogues.text: Let’s get your baby out.  109.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The nurses help Cleo move onto the gurney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fluorescent lights in a hallway with half-open frosted do The cries of a woman giving brith filter out from one of labor rooms. A nurse comes out of one of the rooms and goes into anoth At the end of the hallway we also hear a door opening, an soon after, Doctor Vélez and her team of nurses and resid appear pushing Cleo on her gurney. When they reach the end of the hallway, they turn and ent

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurses and residents work around Cleo who moans in pain. put her on the birthing bed while Doctor Vélez washes her hands.

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: Rubén Lefiero’s colleague is telling me that they've hospitalized injured students and some Halcones came in to kill them off inside the very hospital. A nurse fixes Cleo’s feet onto the braces. Doctor Vélez s in front of her legs to deliver the baby. Cleo has a strong contraction -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Aaaaaaaahhhhhh!

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ
dialogues.text: Don’t blow, Cleo. Push! Cleo tries blowing in the middle of her cries of pain. A doctor comes in the door accompanied by a nurse who wheel a cart with medical equipment. It’s the PEDIATRICIAN. Cleo breathes, agitated. And from between her legs, the baby’s crown appears, like a rising sun.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Almost there... Push!  110.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cleo screams.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaahhhhhhbhhhhhhhh! It's a deep cry. A primeval scream from time immemorial.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaahhhhhhhhhhhhh! The baby is expelled between Cleo’s legs and onto the han of Doctor Vélez, who receives it. The baby doesn’t cry or breathe. It is flaccid and hangs like a rag. It’s complet smeared in green liquid. Doctor Vélez cuts the umbilical chord and passes the baby over to the pediatrician who places it softly on his pediatric table and checks on it with a Pinard stethoscop Cleo follows all the action, the pediatric table only a y away from her face.

dialogues.speaker: PEDIATRICIAN
dialogues.text: No heart beat. We'll try reanimation. The pediatrician places the baby in hyperflexed position puts the laryngoscope down its mouth. He begins aspiratio with a catheter. Cleo sees her baby. From its mouth, through the catheter, meconium comes out, a green dense liquid like pea soup. The pediatrician pulls the catheter out of the baby’s mou and places the “ambu”, a manual resuscitator, on the baby mouth and nose. Doctor Vélez is working on the placenta expulsion. Cleo watches the baby on the table. The Pediatrician pump the “ambu” balloon repeatedly, attempting to reanimate th baby. Cleo looks at the baby, its face almost entirely covered the “ambu” and finds out it’s a girl. The Pediatrician stops pumping the “ambu” and checks for heartbeat with the stethoscope - PEDIATRICIAN (CONT’D) Still asystole... And he walks over, softly, to Cleo  111. PEDIATRICIAN (CONT’D) Ma'am. I am afraid you’re baby is stillborn. She had no amniotic liquid. And the green liquid blocked her lungs. I am so sorry, senora. Cleo listens in silence, unable to take her eyes off her baby. The nurses start cleaning off its tiny body.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ
dialogues.text: I am so sorry, Cleo...

dialogues.speaker: PEDIATRICIAN
dialogues.text: Would you like to say good bye to your baby, ma'am? Cleo nods. The nurses carry the baby and place it quietly Cleo, who hugs it, her gaze lost. Doctor Vélez keeps work between her legs, cleaning her. PEDIATRICIAN (CONT’D) Who are you with? Can we call someone?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ
dialogues.text: She's with family. They’re outside. Cleo whispers something.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you say something, Cleo. I couldn’t hear you...

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: (whispering) Sefiora Sofia... Sefiora Sofia...

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR VELEZ
dialogues.text: Yes, Cleo, I will give her a call... The nurses come to take the dead baby -

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: May I? Ma'am? Cleo nods and the nurse takes the baby over to a small ta where they wrap her in a cloth. Cleo watches as her baby girl disappears under the sheath and when she is completely wrapped, the nurse seals the c with adhesive tape.  112.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The nurse takes a marker and writes on the sheath - NEWBORN —- CLEODEGARIA GUTIERREZ. Friday, June 11, 1971. The light of a new day floods the room. Beds in a row alo the walls, mothers who have recently given birth are rest Some women carry their babies. Others breastfeed. Some sl There are bows, envelopes, flowers. Cleo is awake, lying in bed. Her gaze is absent. A nurse carries a baby up to a bed. A woman holds it, excitedly and begins to breastfeed. The nurse helps her, of them whisper effusively, interrupting the peace in the room. Cleo doesn’t turn to look at them, or perhaps she can’t h them, her gaze is lost. Sefiora Sofia comes to the door and stops for a moment. S watches Cleo, who is motionless, surrounded by the low hu barely awakened traffic from Avenida Cuauhtémoc and the breastfeeding woman’s effusive whispers. Sefiora Sofia comes into the hall and walks towards Cleo. sits on the bed and holds her hand. Cleo looks at her, an attempts a feeble smile. Sefiora Sofia squeezes her hand as her wounded heart trie offer solid support that Cleo can’t find in the void.

dialogues.speaker: HUATABAMPO CROSSTREETS
dialogues.text: Sefiora Sofia is driving. Next to her, Cleo. They are sil They turn right, leaving Baja California Ave behind and w it, the sun. They drive down Ures, both look straight ahead, surrounde the purr of eight cylinders changing gears automatically. They turn left, onto Huatabampo streets. They continue in silence under the shade of the houses until they reach th corner with Tonald, where a car waits its turn to turn.  113.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sefiora Sofia breaks behind the car and waits. The two wo look ahead in silence. Sefiora Sofia holds Cleo’s hand an starts bawling. It’s a quiet and prolonged wail that breaks into a long a articulate lament. She hugs Cleo who is still silent. The car in front of them has moved and now the GALAXIE ho up the traffic, three cars waiting behind it already. A H honks. Sefiora Sofia cries while hugging Cleo. She cries out all impotence, all the fear, all the uncertainty, and all the humiliation. She cries, ignoring the chorus of horns that joined her lament.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Galaxie 500 is motionless and stops traffic at the corner. Impatiently, cars go around it on the left, some them protesting rudely. The two women inside the Galaxie continue to hug. Wednesday, June 23, 1971.

dialogues.speaker: EXT- PATIO
dialogues.text: Littered with dog shit, the patio is empty except for a r tricycle, a football and Borras, enjoying the last few ra of sun. A mysterious WHISTLE filters in from the distance. Alert, Borras lifts his head. The sad and solitary whistle invokes a presence, invading walls of the house. In the patio, Borras begins to bark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whistle pierces through the afternoon quiet and seems bounce off the facades of the houses. Sad and defeated, Tepeji 21 rests on its solid ground, wh blends with the grey concrete of the sidewalk.  114. The Galaxie 500 and the Valiant are parked in front of th house. A KNIFE SHARPENER crosses on his bike, blowing on his whistle, suffusing the air with its ominous lament.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The parakeets seem to want to imitate the whistle with th song. Adela’s voice calls from the second floor -

dialogues.speaker: ADELA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Move it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleo is sitting next to the window, wrapped up in her own pain.

dialogues.speaker: ADELA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: It’s the sharpener! Move it! Cleo! But Cleo remains motionless. The fateful whistle fades away slowly and disappears. Borras and the parakeets calm down. Everything is in silence. The afternoon light abates. Cleo doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: TA-TA TA-TA TA-TA TA-TAAAAAAA...
dialogues.text: A car's nasal horn resounds on the street and Borras repl with his barks.

dialogues.speaker: TA-TA TA-TA TA-TA TA-TAAAAAAA...
dialogues.text: Cleo does not recognize the sound of the horn but its rhy

dialogues.speaker: TA-TA TA-TA TA-TA TA-TAAAAAAA...
dialogues.text: Cleo gets up and slowly walks out the door to the - SMALL PATIO -— She crosses out onto -  115.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleo watches Adela open the street door while she grabs Borras by the collar. She discovers - A PALE YELLOW RENAULT 21 parked in front of the door. It and pulls in, easily crossing the doorframe and continuin its way up to the hallway door. Paco and Pepe peek out from the hall and see their mother the wheel of the Renault. Paco cries out -

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Tofio! Sofi! Come!

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Mom bought a new car! Paco comes out to examine the car’s body. Pepe joins his brother. Cleo comes closer while Adela closes the door th leads to the street. Sefiora Sofia pokes her head out of the car window -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: You like it?

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: How fast can it go? Sefiora Sofia opens the door and comes out -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: You check. Paco hurries to sit in the driver’s seat. Pepe runs aroun the other side and sits in the passenger seat. Tofio and Sofi come out to the patio to see the new car.

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: Why not a Maverick? From the driver’s seat, Paco protests -

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: It only goes to 145! The Galaxie goes up to 200!

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Because they’re very expensive and I want a small car. I’ve had it up to here with that Galaxie!  116.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sofi sits in the back seat -

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: I like the new car, mommy.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: What about the Galaxie?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: I sold it. They’re coming to pick it up next week. Sofi comes out of the car -

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Does dad know?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: No, it’s a surprise. Sefiora Sofia looks at Cleo - SENORA SOF{A (CONT’D) Hi, Cleo. Do you like the new car? Cleo barely nods.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOF
dialogues.text: And speaking of surprises, we're going on a trip this weekend and we're taking the Galaxie on its goodbye ride. Paco and Pepe come out of the car and follow their mother siblings into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Where to?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Tuxpan.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Where’s Tuxpan?

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: I have practice!

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: You'll skip it. Tuxpan is in Veracruz.  117.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: From the patio and through the window, Cleo watches the lights of the house switching on and Sefora Sofia crossin the hall up to the stairs. Paco and Pepe cross the hall following their mother.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: It’s the beach?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: The beach in Veracruz is so ugly. Sefiora Sofia climbs the stairs, the four children follow Out on the patio, Cleo watches the family disappear into upper floor. Saturday, June 26, 1971

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Palm trees, ceibas and banana plants give way to multicol houses competing with tropical flowers and foliage and mo palm trees, ceibas and banana plants. The Galaxie 500 drives past a turn.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT
dialogues.text: Cleo watches the landscape in silence, Pepe snuggles agai her. The radio's looking to tune into a station, going through tropical music, cumbias, and advertisements for a local dance.

dialogues.speaker: TONO, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: La Pantera doesn’t get all the way here.

dialogues.speaker: PACO, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I heard it for a little bit.  118.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Look! The sea!

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Stop, stop, stop! Ma!

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Why don’t we go drop the bags off at the hotel first?

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: By the time we get there it’1ll be dark.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Let’s go! Just for a little while.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: OK. Only for a little bit though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Galaxie pulls up next to the sands of a long grey overcast beach, empty except for the stunted skeleton of brick building. The family comes out of the car. Tofio and Paco immediately run to the shore taking off th shirts and pants and throwing them on the sand. Sofi and follow behind. Sefiora Sofia takes off her shoes and follows her childre picking up the clothes strewn about on the sand. Cleo walks to the shore where the children splash around. is absent. A gust of wind drags the breeze over to caress her face. breathes in the sea and closes her eyes. She breathes in, if wanting to cleanse something very deep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fading light of day strokes the garden with soft coolness. An orchard surrounds the bungalows built in the 1940s their paint now nibbled on by time and saltpeter. A RECEPTIONIST, carrying keys, guides Sefiora Sofia, Cleo the children through the garden. They all carry bags. The receptionist opens the door.  119. INT. —- ROOM - BUNGALOW - TUXPAN - DUSK The sky’s last light attempts to paint the windows but is defeated by the lightbulb inside a wicker lamp, which lig the small room with two beds. Cleo, sits on one of the beds and putting Pepe’s T-shirt as he stands in front of her with his arms up in the air. When his head pokes out the collar, Pepe looks at her, surprised -—

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Cat got your tongue? Cleo shakes her head no.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then why don’t you talk. Cleo smiles, with a smile that holds back tears, and walk him out of the room to a - INT. — LIVING ROOM - BUNGALOW - TUXPAN - DUSK Another wicker lamp hangs in the middle of the little din room and two lamps on each side of the sofa, one without shade, light the room. Tofio is tying knots with a string while Sefiora Sofia is applying vinegar on Paco’s back with a cotton ball.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Ay! Ay ! Ay...!

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: I told you to put on your T-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: But it was cloudy!

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: That's why! The glare is worse than the sun! Next to him, crying and crying, Sofi waits her turn.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOF
dialogues.text: Are you dressed Pepe?

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Yes, but the cat got Cleo’s tongue.  120.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sefiora Sofia smiles. Cleo sits on the sofa and grabs a c ball, douses it in vinegar, comes close to Sofi and start applying it on her back. Cleo and Sefiora Sofia swab wet cotton balls over Sofi an Paco's backs. Sofi won't stop crying but Cleo’s gaze is absent. INT. —- RESTAURANT —- TUXPAN - NIGHT Hand-drawn illustrations of each dish and a stuffed sailf decorate the walls of a family restaurant. Romantic music pours out of a rockola, accompanying the hum of the fluorescent lights. The family’s finishing dinner. Cleo cuts Sofi and Pepe’s meat. They’re wearing pajamas already.
