Tofio has finished is tying his knots.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Children? But the children are distracted.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOF
dialogues.text: Children? She finally gets her children’s attention.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOF
dialogues.text: Pay attention! I have something to tell you. The children look at her expectantly. Sefiora Sofia hesit gathers her courage and - SENORA SOF{A (CONT’D) Your dad's not in Ottawa.

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Is he back?!

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: No. Your dad never went anywhere. The children look at her, she’s seems confused.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOF
dialogues.text: Well, yes. But he only went for a week and... your father’s not coming back home.  121.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The children watch her in silence. Tofio and Paco are interested, Sofi and Pepe are confused. The song ends and the rockola digests another coin, expel a new lament. SENORA SOF{A (CONT’D) We came on this trip so he could come get his things from the house.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: What things?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: His things. Or what he says are his things. His clothes, the bookshelves...

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Are you getting a divorce?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: He says he doesn’t know. Sofi starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: He doesn’t love us anymore?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Dad loves you very much. He says he wants to see you.

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: He says he doesn’t know when... Soon. Sofi muffles her cries in Cleo’s breast, Tofio looks at t fan and Paco plays with his beans. Only Pepe is still loo at his mother, still confused.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOF
dialogues.text: There will be many changes, but we'll be together and it’1l be an adventure. Pepe rests his head on Cleo.  122.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOF
dialogues.text: I’m starting a new full time job in publishing next week.

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: Publishing? But you’re a chemist.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: I know, but your father hasn’t sent any money yet and teaching high school is not enough. Plus, I love books and I never liked chemistry. It’ll be another adventure. But the children don’t look very convinced. They still do know this but this moment will be etched into their memor as fragments of images, smells, sounds and textures - The food stains on the table, the paintings on the walls, landscape of beans smashed by the fork on a plate. The song ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family roams around the streets. Quiet. Lost in thoug Sunday June 27, 1971.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun bears down on the afternoon, beaming down on the waves and the burning sand on the empty beach. The waves follow one after another, incessantly, dragging their foa till they caress the sand without ever breaking. A palapa shelters the family under its shade and its cool sand. Paco and Pepe bury Sofi in the sand, sculpting long legs which they add tennis shoes instead of feet. Sefiora Sofia reads a book sitting on a folding cloth cha and Tofio reads a Flash comic lying down on a hammock, sw in the wind.  123. At the edge of the shade, Cleo is sitting on a chair, hypnotized by the rhythm of the waves and the foam meltin it touches the sand. Time trickles by slowly.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The yellow end-of-the-afternoon light dances with the win caressing surfaces softly. Paco and Sofi play in the waves, jumping over them, swimm under them, or resisting heroically on foot. In her dress, Cleo stands next to Pepe who is digging hol tunnels and roads in the sand too. Sefiora Sofia comes in to the edge, followed by Tofio who halfway. Paco and Sofi come out of the water running -

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Are you going to come in?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: I have to go check on the tires since we're leaving tomorrow early. You coming?

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: No. It’s our last day at the beach.

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: I’m staying too.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: But if I leave, you can’t go in. If something happens, Cleo can’t swim.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: But it’s so mellow.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: I don’t care. If you want to stay, those are the rules.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Not even by the edge?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: By the edge is fine. But just here, understood?

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Me too?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Yes, but right by the shore. Sefiora Sofia looks at Cleo. SENORA SOF{A (CONT’D) Can I leave them with you? I won't take long. Cleo simply nods and watches Sefiora Sofia walk back with to the Galaxie 500 parked behind the palapa. In the background, the sun has lost its shine and peeks o red and roundly from between the clouds. Paco and Sofi go back to the water, Pepe follows.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Just right by the shore. Paco and Sofi run to the edge, splashing around with thei feet, getting Pepe wet.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Aaaah! Paco and Sofi kick more water around to get Pepe wet, he away but falls on dry sand. Cleo runs to him and picks hi up, he’s crying. She tries to brush off the thousands of grains of sand sticking to his damp skin. Paco takes advantage of the distraction and goes in deepe Sofi begins to follow in after him when Cleo sees them -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Paco! Just in the shallow water! Sofi! Sofi obeys, Paco comes back to the shore too. Cleo takes Pepe’s hand and they walk back to the palapa together. As they step on warmer sand, Pepe stops, holds arms up.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Carry me.  125.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: No way. You can do it alone. It’s not hot anymore. She looks to the shore -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Paco! I see you! Back to the shore!

dialogues.speaker: PACO, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: But we’re at the shore!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Come closer! You heard your mother, if you don’t come in, you have to get out! She waits and when she’s satisfied, she keeps walking. Arms still up in the air, Pepe watches her go and throws himself on the sand. Cleo barely looks -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Suit yourself. You’re just getting more sand on you and I was going to clean you up in the palapa. She keeps walking. Pepe gets up, crusty with sand, and hurries to catch up. They reach the palapa and Pepe sits on a chair. Cleo star dusting him off with a clean towel. She looks to the sea

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! I’m watching you guys! Cleo waits for the children to come back to shallow water keeps cleaning Pepe.

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Did you know when I was grown up I was a sailor?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Mmmhmmm. . .

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Yes, and I drowned in a storm.  126.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Mmmhmmm. . . She gets up and looks out to sea -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Paco and Sofi! Closer! Cleo keeps watching -

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: But the waves were so big....

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Get back! She walks to the edge of the palapa and stops to wait nex a post -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Closer!

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: And it was night and there was so much lightning... and I didn’t know how to swim... Without taking her eyes from the waves, Cleo starts walki towards the shore.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Stay there Pepe. The sun has vanished behind the mountain and the purple s is laden with black clouds. The wind picks up the sand an makes new waves that crash arrogantly into the old ones. Cleo stops -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Help your sister! Behind her, Pepe comes closer. Cleo sees him -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pepe! I told you to stay there! Chided, Pepe goes back to the palapa. Scared now, Cleo looks at the sea and looks around but th beach is deserted. Only a man on a horse far away and som people walking in the distance. She hurries to the shore.  127. As she reaches the edge, she walks fearfully in the water that moves back and forth and crashes around her legs, soaking her polyester dress. She looks impotently at the waves, which Paco and Sofi wrestle, insignificant in a fierce and indifferent ocean drags them further in. Cleo tries to move closer to the children, fighting to ke her balance in the choppy waters reaching her waist. The wind plays with the crests of the dark waves and the dense clouds are charged with tension in an ever darkenin sky. Cleo looks out to the beach but the man on the horse and people are still very far away and she resigns herself to going deeper. A wave crashes over the children’s heads. When it passes, Sofi reemerges but she can barely take a breath when anot waves comes crashing over her. Other waves cross and crash up to the sky. Cleo fights desperately to stay on her feet in the midst the cross-current chaos enveloping her without failing to look straight in front of her- Where the waves crash, rising up, and yet others take the place, the little heads don’t emerge. Another wave powers up and a little head bobs up in front her, it’s Sofi taking up air, and Paco resurfaces too. He turns to look and sizes up the wave, grabs his sister swims with the break to the beach, but the wave catches u with them, pulling them down. Cleo comes close but is pushed back by the waves. In fron her, the little heads reemerge. Paco tries to repeat the and pushes Sofi to the front, but the water envelops them It also envelops Cleo, but doesn’t drag her out. She push towards Sofi, who tries to swim to her. Cleo reaches her out to get her and as she pulls her in, her feet lose con with the bottom and the two go under. Another wave galloping with foam. And behind it, Cleo eme carrying Sofi. Paco swims behind them. At the beach, a group of people gathers, and with them th man on the horse.  128.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cleo carries Sofi and finally manages to reach shallower waters, Paco follows a little further behind. A couple of young guys run towards them but they don’t help, they jus look. Carrying Sofi, Cleo reaches the shore and collapses on th beach, Paco next to her. Sofi coughs and Cleo hugs her on lap. Curious onlookers surround them and behind them, Sefiora Sofia, followed by Tofio come running from the palapa. Cleo cleans sand off of Sofi’s face and starts crying. Sh cries and hugs Sofi who is also crying, and rocks with he Cleo hugs her as if her life depended on it. Sefiora Sofia throws herself on the sand next to Cleo and yanks Sofi from her. Sofi hugs her mom. Paco comes to the and hugs them both. Tofio watches, next to the bystanders, and next to him Pe looks scared. Sefiora Sofia checks on Sofi -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Are you OK, my love? Sofi nods -

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Cleo saved us... The recent emotion pushes more tears. Sefiora Sofi looks Cleo who is crying inconsolably. It’s a deep and painful a cry that washes it all away. Sefiora Sofia hugs her mightily -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Thank you, thank you, thank you Cleo... But Cleo can’t stop crying -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I didn’t want her... I didn’t want her... Sefiora Sofia tries to calm her -  129.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Shhh, shhh, shhh... They’re OK. The kids are OK.... But Cleo insists amidst tears and snot -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I didn’t want her... I didn’t want her to be born... She breaks down completely -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Poor little girl! ... I didn’t want her to be born! ... I didn’t want her to be born!...

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: It’s going to be all right, Cleo... It’s going to be all right... The two women cry, hugging. It’s a shared cry, with sobs retching, and long silences exploding in prolonged vocals The children close in on the women, hugging them. Only To watches, standing by. The onlookers scatter. The rider pulls the reins and the horse continues its way down the beach. The furious sea and its restless waves reflect the last glimmers of the day. Monday June 28, 1971.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fields spotted with clouds spread out between green hills Further behind, the volcanos show off their snowy peaks. The Galaxie 500 drives on, tiny, on the road crossing the landscape.  130.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT
dialogues.text: Sefiora Sofia is driving, and her index finger is calm. N to her, Tofio looks out the window without looking at the landscape. In the rear, Paco also lets the landscape slid his lost gaze. Sofi is hugging Cleo, who carries a sleeping Pepe on her The family rides in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mexico City extends out to the distance. The Galaxie 500 drives on, heavy with uncertainty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house rests patiently, resigned to enjoy the last ray sun. The Jr. high marching band turns the corner and heads int the street with its martial drums and trumpets. The Galaxie 500 pulls into the street and follows the ban read guard until it parks in front of the house. Tofio immediately opens the door and stretches out on the stree Pepe comes out after him, running to the door, holding hi privates and ringing the doorbell. Borras answers by bark Sefiora Sofia comes out of the car and opens the trunk, S comes out after her. Cleo comes out last and heads to the trunk as well. Adela opens the door holding Borras by the collar. Pepe r through the door and rushes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The afternoon sun still pierces the windows obliquely and streaks the living room shadows with its light. Outside t family is on the sidewalk -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Tie the dog...

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: You too, kids. Don’t play dumb and come help us with the things.  131.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The children who were already walking up to the house sto and come back to help begrudgingly. Inside, the skylight lights the stairs but barely touches tiles in the hall. Pepe bursts in from the patio and runs the bathroom that is under the stairs, goes in, shuts the door. Adela crosses through the windows that open to the patio, dragging Borras by the collar. She listens to the jet in toilet. Inside, the house waits. It seems to have grown larger. T absence of the bookshelves has left towers of books piled the floor and a seeming emptiness. Tofio comes in, carrying his things. He’s rushing but sto the middle of the hall, surprised by the space-it seems n Paco comes in right after and stops next to his brother. Sefiora Sofia walks in with Sofi. The toilet flushes and reaches his verdict -

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: It’s horrible. It’s horrible without the bookshelves...

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: I like it better this way... Tofio runs up the stairs...

dialogues.speaker: TONO
dialogues.text: It’s awful. Paco follows after him. Pepe comes out of the bathroom an follows his mother and Sofi up the stairs -

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: What’s so horrible mommy?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: He doesn’t like the hallway without the bookshelves.

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: What bookshelves?

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: The ones that used to be in the hall.  132.

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Oh! You’re right!

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Wow! It looks bigger!

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: What did you think about our adventure?

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: I liked it a lot. Sefiora Sofia and the children disappear upstairs, where television is already on. Outside, on the patio, Cleo walks, carrying three bags an runs into Adela who is back without the dog.

dialogues.speaker: ADELA
dialogues.text: I’m going to the store, there’s no ham. How was it then?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Real pretty. Go. I’1ll tell you about it later. Adela continues on her way out. Cleo comes into the hall. Crosses and goes up the stairs carrying the luggage. From upstairs Pepe exclaims -

dialogues.speaker: PEPE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The desk is gone too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleo makes it up to the hall and leaves the luggage on th floor. The family has begun to take over the spaces - Pepe sits next to Paco who is already in front of the television.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: And we'll have other adventures. And we’ll travel a lot.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: We'll go to Dinseyland?  133.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tofio puts stuff away in a drawer in his room and Sofi go her room to grab a doll. Sefiora Sofia goes to Cleo, take of the bags and puts it in her room -—

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: We don’t have enough money... Cleo takes the other bag to Tofio and Paco’s room. Tofio out and sits in the armchair in front of the television.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOF
dialogues.text: But we can go on adventures in the car. What if we went to a ghost mining town in the desert?

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: And there’s ghosts? Paco gets up, following his mother into her room —

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: No, silly. That’s what you call towns that are abandoned. And what’s over there? Cleo comes out of Tofio’s room carrying a load of laundry drops it next to the stairs. Sefiora Sofia comes out of her room followed by Paco. The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Nothing. Just the town and the abandoned mine. Or we could go to the Lacandon jungle, or Oaxaca...

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Oaxaca, Yes! And we could visit Cleo’s village. Sefiora Sofia comes back to the hall and sits in the couc next to Pepe and Sofi who takes up the other spot.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: I was there.

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Finders keepers... Cleo picks up...  134.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Hello? Yes, thank you ma’am... Yes just a moment... She lowers the phone and calls out -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sefiora Sofi? It’s sefiora Molly calling. Sefiora Sofia gets up, calming the children -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Don’t fight. You sit here, Paco. She goes up to the phone -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOF
dialogues.text: Hello, comadre. How are you? I’m just back from Tuxpan... Cleo gathers the dirty laundry into a pile. Pepe calls fr the couch -

dialogues.speaker: PEPE
dialogues.text: Cleo? Can you bring me a banana milkshake?

dialogues.speaker: SOFI
dialogues.text: Me too? Cleo picks up the pile of clothes -

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Sure. Just lemme take these clothes up to wash. Do you want something, Paco?

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Any Gansitos?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I’m not sure, but if not, I'll go get some later. Cleo starts to go down the stairs. Sefiora Sofia continue phone conversation -

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA
dialogues.text: Yes, it was wonderful... Yes, the kids are all right... No... lovely! «ee. good... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: SENORA SOFIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well Paco and Sofi scared the living daylights out of me...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Cleo goes down the stairs carrying her pile of clothes, t family conversations and television filter down from upstairs. As she reaches downstairs, she crosses the empty hallway the breakfast room. She goes into the kitchen and out the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The patio, in shadows now, floats in the afternoon quiet. Borras sleeps and the parakeets are quiet. Only the hum o the city in the distance. Cleo comes out of the kitchen carrying her load of dirty laundry and crosses the tiny patio to go up the metal staircase that leads to the roof. Her steps reverberate throughout the bony structure in a metallic moan that echoes through the tiny patio, waking caged birds. Cleo reaches the step in front of her room and keeps walk upwards. A sweet potato vendor lets out his sad howl in t distance. Step by step, Cleo ascends. Yet further up, beyond the roof, the sky is pure. Pietrasanta, September 23, 2016.
